title:
Lipschitz geometry of complex surface germs via inner rates of primary
  ideals

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Let $(X, 0)$ be a normal complex surface germ embedded in $\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}, 0\right)$, and denote by m the maximal ideal of the local ring $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. In this paper, we associate to each m-primary ideal $I$ of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$ a continuous function $\mathcal{I}_{I}$ defined on the set of positive (suitably normalized) semivaluations of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. We prove that the function $\mathcal{I}_{\mathrm{m}}$ is determined by the outer Lipschitz geometry of the surface $(X, 0)$. We further demonstrate that for each m -primary ideal $I$, there exists a complex surface germ $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ with an isolated singularity whose normalization is isomorphic to $(X, 0)$ and $\mathcal{I}_{I}=\mathcal{I}_{\mathrm{m}_{I}}$, where $\mathrm{m}_{I}$ is the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X_{I}, 0}$. Subsequently, we construct an infinite family of complex surface germs with isolated singularities, whose normalizations are isomorphic to $(X, 0)$ (in particular, they are homeomorphic to $(X, 0)$ ) but have distinct outer Lipschitz types.

## QUICK OVERVIEW

Let $(X, 0)$ be a germ of complex space embedded in $\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}, 0\right)$. It is well known that the topological type of $(X, 0)$, that is its class of homeomorphism, determines and is determined by the homeomorphism class of its link $X^{(\epsilon)}=X \cap S_{\epsilon}^{2 n-1}$ for $\epsilon>0$ sufficiently small, where $S_{\epsilon}^{2 n-1}$ is the sphere of

[^0]
[^0]:    2020 Mathematics Subject Classification. Primary 32S05, 32S25, 32B10 Secondary 14J17, 14B05, 32S55.
    Key words and phrases. Complex Surface Singularities, Resolution Of Singularities, Polar Curves, Lipschitz Geometry, Non Archimedean Geometry.

radius $\epsilon$. Thanks to this result, the topology of germs of complex spaces is quite well understood; however, it is not the case for their metric type, and that is what we are going to investigate in this paper.

Let us first give some historical context: the standard metric of $\mathbb{C}^{n}$ induces two natural distances on $(X, 0)$. The outer metric, denoted $d_{o}$, is defined by restricting the Euclidean distance of $\mathbb{C}^{n}$ to $X$, and the inner metric, referred to as $d_{i}$, quantifies the lengths of arcs on $X$. There are many motivations to study these metrics. Among them is the fact that the biholomorphic class of the germ $(X, 0)$ determines the inner (resp. outer) Lipschitz geometry of $(X, 0)$ (see Definition 5.11). Another motivation arises from a result by Mostowski in [Mos85], which asserts that the set of complex germs up to bilipschitz equivalence with respect to the inner (resp. outer) metric is countable. This result was significantly generalized by Parusiński in [Par94] for the real case and then Nhan and Valette in [NV16] for more general O-minimal structures.

The complete classification of complex germs under bilipschitz equivalence is then more attainable compared to the analytic classification and, as expected, richer than the topological classification. However, in the case of germs of complex curves, the difference between Lipschitz geometry and topology does not appear. Indeed, a germ of curve $(C, 0)$ embedded in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$ is metrically conical, meaning that it is inner bilipschitz equivalent to the cone over its link $C^{\epsilon}=C \cap \mathbb{S}_{\epsilon}$. As for the outer metric, it follows from the work of Teissier in [Tei82] that any curve germ $(C, 0) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}, 0\right)$ is outer bilipschitz equivalent to a germ of a complex plane curve (embedded in $\mathbb{C}^{2}$ ). Later, Neumann and Pichon proved in [NP14] that the outer Lipschitz geometry of a plane curve germ $(C, 0) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0\right)$ determines and is determined by the embedded topological type of the curve germ.

More recently, Neumann, Birbrair, and Pichon gave a complete classification of complex surface germs with isolated singularities up to bilipschitz equivalence with respect to the inner metric by means of the inner rates of complex surface germs (see Definition 2.18), a topic we elaborate on in this paper. Furthermore, Neumann and Pichon's work in [NP16] establishes a connection between the outer metric of a complex surface germ $(X, 0) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}, 0\right)$ and the families of generic hyperplane sections and generic polar curves of $(X, 0)$ (see Definitions 1.14 and 2.18). Their result roughly states that the outer Lipschitz geometry of $(X, 0)$ determines the relative position between these families of curves.

In an early study, Belotto, Fantini, Némethi, and Pichon proved in [BdSFNP22] that when the homeomorphism class of a normal surface germ $(X, 0)$ is fixed, there are, up to homeomorphism, only finitely many possible relative positions between the family of generic hyperplane sections and the family of polar curves associated with the generic projections on $(X, 0)$.

In this paper, we investigate what happens to the last mentioned result when we do not assume the normality of the complex surface germ $(X, 0)$. Our result (Theorem A) essentially states that when the homeomorphism class of the germ $(X, 0)$ and the analytic type of its normalization $(\bar{X}, 0)$ are fixed, there are, up to homeomorphism, infinitely many possible relative positions between the generic hyperplane sections and the generic polar curves of $(X, 0)$. In particular, it follows from our result and the work of Neumann and Pichon described earlier that there are infinitely many outer Lipschitz geometries on complex surface germs even when we fix the homeomorphism class of the germs and the analytic type of their normalization.

# CONTENT OF THE PAPER 

In order to state our result precisely, we need to introduce some terminology first. Let $\pi$ : $\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution of $(X, 0)$, that is, a proper bimeromorphic map which is an isomorphism outside of a simple normal crossing divisor $\pi^{-1}(0)=E$, called the exceptional divisor. Let $\Gamma_{\pi}$ be the dual graph associated with $\pi$, that is, the graph whose vertices are in bijection with the irreducible components of $E$ and such that the edges between two vertices $v$ and $v^{\prime}$ correspond

to the intersecting points between the components $E_{v}$ and $E_{v^{\prime}}$. Each vertex $v$ of this graph is weighted with the self-intersection number $E_{v}^{2}$ and the genus $g_{v}$ of the corresponding compact complex curve $E_{v}$. Given a holomorphic function $\underline{f}:(X, 0) \longrightarrow(\mathbb{C}, 0)$, we denote by $f^{*}$ the strict transform of $f$ by $\pi$, that is, the curve $f^{*}:=\overline{\pi^{-1}\left(f^{-1}(0)\right) \backslash E}$. The following notations were introduced in [BdSFNP22]: given a vertex $v$ of $\Gamma_{\pi}$, we denote by $\ell_{v}$ the intersection multiplicity $\ell^{*} \cdot E_{v}$, where $\ell:(X, 0) \longrightarrow(\mathbb{C}, 0)$ is a generic linear form in the sense of [BdSFP22] (see Definition 2.18). We denote by $p_{v}$ the intersection multiplicity $\Pi \cdot E_{v}$ where $\Pi$ is the polar curve associated with a generic linear projection $P:(X, 0) \longrightarrow\left(\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0\right)$ again in the sense of [BdSFP22] (see Definition 2.18). The blow up of the maximal ideal (see Definition 2.3) is the minimal modification which resolves the family of generic hyperplane sections (See Definition 2.18) of $(X, 0)$. The Nash transform (see Definition 2.16) is the minimal modification which resolves the family of generic polar curves, that is, the polar curves associated with the generic plane linear projections. We associate to the minimal good resolution $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$, which factors through the blow up of the maximal ideal and the Nash transform a triple $\left(\Gamma_{\pi}, L_{\pi}, P_{\pi}\right)$ where $L_{\pi}=\left(\ell_{v}\right)_{v \in V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)}$ and $P_{\pi}=\left(p_{v}\right)_{v \in V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)}$, where $V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)$ denotes the set of vertices of $\Gamma_{\pi}$. Before stating our result, we will first recall a result of Belotto, Fantini, Némethi, and Pichon, which will give a bit more context.
Theorem ([BdSFNP22, Theorem A]). Let $M$ be a real 3-manifold. There exists finitely many triple $(\Gamma, L, P)$, where $\Gamma$ is a weighted graph and $L$ and $P$ are vectors in $\left(\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}\right)^{V(\Gamma)}$, such that there exists a normal complex surface germ $(X, 0)$ satisfying the following conditions:
(i) The link of $(X, 0)$ is homeomorphic to $M$.
(ii) $(\Gamma, L, P)=\left(\Gamma_{\pi}, L_{\pi}, P_{\pi}\right)$.

In this paper, we investigate the following question: Does the statement of Theorem [BdSFNP22, Theorem A] still hold if we relax the hypothesis from a normal complex surface germ to a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity ? The following result give a negative answer to this question
Theorem A (Theorem 5.3). Let $(X, 0)$ be a normal complex surface germ. Let $\Lambda_{X}$ be the infinite set of integrally closed $\mathfrak{m}$-primary ideals of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. There exists a family of complex surface germs with an isolated singularity $\left\{\left(X_{I}, 0\right)\right\}_{I \in \Lambda_{X}}$ such that
(i) $(X, 0)$ is homeomorphic to $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ for all $I \in \Lambda_{X}$ and is the common normalization of the germs $\left\{\left(X_{I}, 0\right)\right\}_{I \in \Lambda_{X}}$.
(ii) For all $I, J$ in $\Lambda_{X}$ we have that $\left(\Gamma_{\pi_{I}}, L_{\pi_{I}}, P_{\pi_{I}}\right)=\left(\Gamma_{\pi_{J}}, L_{\pi_{J}}, P_{\pi_{J}}\right)$ if and only if $I=J$. where $\pi_{I}$ and $\pi_{J}$ are the minimal good resolutions which factors through the blow-ups of the maximal ideal and the Nash transform of $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ and $\left(X_{J}, 0\right)$ respectively.
We can apply this result to the study of the Lipschitz geometry of complex surface germs by combining it with the following result of Neumann and Pichon:
Theorem ([NP16, Theorem 1.2]). Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity. Then the outer Lipschitz geometry of $X$ determines the triple $\left(\Gamma_{\pi}, L_{\pi}, P_{\pi}\right)$ where $\pi$ is the minimal good resolution which factors through the blow-up of the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$ and the Nash transform of $(X, 0)$.

As a consequence of this last result and Theorem A we get the following
Corollary B (Corollary 5.12). Let $(X, 0)$ be a normal complex surface germ. Let $\Lambda_{X}$ be the infinite set of integrally closed $\mathfrak{m}$-primary ideals of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. There exists a family of complex surface germs with an isolated singularity $\left\{\left(X_{I}, 0\right)\right\}_{I \in \Lambda_{X}}$ such that
(i) $(X, 0)$ is homeomorphic to $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ for all $I \in \Lambda_{X}$ and is the common normalization of the germs $\left\{\left(X_{I}, 0\right)\right\}_{I \in \Lambda_{X}}$.

(ii) For all $I, J \in \Lambda_{X}$ the surfaces $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ and $\left(X_{J}, 0\right)$ are outer Lipschitz equivalent if and only if $I=J$.

Even though it does not appear in the statements of Theorem A and Corollary B, the family of surfaces $\left\{\left(X_{I}, 0\right)\right\}_{I \in \Lambda_{X}}$ can be explicitly constructed. In what follows, we will introduce the required tools and results needed for such a construction. Besides proving Theorem A, the following results and constructions have their own independent interest.

We introduce an infinite family of numerical analytic invariants of $(X, 0) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}, 0\right)$ associated with an $\mathfrak{m}$-primary ideal $I$ of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$ : let $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution and $E_{v}$ be an irreducible component of $E$. The inner rate of $I$ along $E_{v}$ is the rational number

$$
q_{v}^{I}:=\frac{\nu_{v}(I)-m_{v}(I)+1}{m_{v}(I)}
$$

where $m_{v}(I):=\inf \left\{\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}(h) \mid h \in I\right\}$, and $\nu_{v}(I):=\inf \left\{\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} h_{1} \wedge \mathrm{~d} h_{2}\right)\right) \mid h_{1}, h_{2} \in I\right\}$. These numbers generalize the notion of inner rates of complex surface germs (See Definition 2.18) first introduced by Birbrair, Neumann, and Pichon in [BNP14] to study the inner Lipschitz geometry of complex surface germs. Indeed, let $\mathcal{N}_{v}$ be a small tubular neighborhood of $E_{v}$ with a small neighborhood of its double points removed. Roughly speaking, the inner rate of $(X, 0)$ along the component $E_{v}$ is a rational number $q_{v}$ that measures how fast the diameter (with respect to the inner metric) of the set $\pi\left(\mathcal{N}_{v}\right) \cap \mathbb{S}_{\epsilon}^{2 n-1}$ tends to zero as $\epsilon$ tends to zero. We explain in Remark 2.19 that the rational number $q_{v}$, as equivalently defined in [BdSFNP22], is equal to the number $q_{v}^{\mathfrak{m}}$, where $\mathfrak{m}$ is the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$.

Studying the inner rates appears to be much more convenient through valuation theory than solely relying on dual graphs. Let us explain why. The Non-archimedean link (See Definition 1.10) is the set of positive and normalized semivaluations defined on the completion of the local ring $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$ endowed with the Tychonoff topology. Among these semivaluations, we have the divisorial valuations defined as follows: for each good resolution $\pi$ of $(X, 0)$ and for every vertex $v$ of $\Gamma_{\pi}$, we define the valuation $\operatorname{val}_{E_{v}}(f):=\frac{\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}(f)}{\inf \left\{\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}(h) \mid h \in \mathfrak{m}\right\}}$, known as the divisorial valuation associated with $E_{v}$. It turns out that the set of divisorial valuations is dense in $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ (See Lemma 1.12). Each dual graph $\Gamma_{\pi}$ embeds into $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ by associating each vertex to its corresponding divisorial valuation. Conversely, $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ can be continuously retracted to $\Gamma_{\pi}$. Thus, we can establish a homeomorphism between the non-archimedean link and the inverse limit of the dual graphs obtained from all good resolutions. The topological space $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ can thus be viewed as a universal dual graph. This construction was first introduced by Favre and Jonsson in [FJ04] for the smooth case. It was generalized to the singular case by Favre in [Fav10].

Next, for each $\mathfrak{m}$-primary ideal $I$ of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$, we define a real continuous function $\mathcal{I}_{I}$ on $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ such that its value on each divisorial valuation $\operatorname{val}_{E_{v}}$ of $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ is the inner rate $q_{v}^{I}$. Furthermore, by equipping $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ with an appropriate metric denoted $\mathrm{d}_{I}$, which depends on the ideal $I$, we demonstrate that the function $\mathcal{I}_{I}$ is linear on each edge of every graph $\Gamma_{\pi}$ where $\pi$ is a good resolution that factors through the blow up of $I$ (see Definition 2.3) and the principalization of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$ (see Definition 2.14), generalizing the inner rate function introduced in [BdSFP22].

The following theorem provides a geometric interpretation of the inner rates associated with an $\mathfrak{m}$-primary ideal $I$ as metric invariants of another surface explicitly constructed using a system of generators of $I$.

Theorem C (Theorem 4.1). Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity and $I$ be a $\mathfrak{m}$-primary ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. There exists a system of generators $F=\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ of $I$ such

that the holomorphic map

$$
\begin{aligned}
F:(X, 0) & \rightarrow(F(X), 0) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}, 0\right) \\
p & \mapsto\left(f_{1}(p), f_{2}(p), \ldots, f_{k}(p)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

verifies the following properties:
(i) The image $(F(X), 0)$ is a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity at the origin of $\mathbb{C}^{k}$.
(ii) The map $F$ is a homeomorphism on its image and a modification of $(F(X), 0)$.
(iii) The induced map $\tilde{F}:\left(\mathrm{NL}(X, 0), \mathrm{d}_{I}\right) \longrightarrow\left(\mathrm{NL}(F(X), 0), \mathrm{d}_{\mathfrak{m}_{F}}\right), \tilde{F}(v)(h)=v(h \circ F), \forall v \in$ $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0), \forall h \in \mathcal{O}_{F(X), 0}$ is an isometry which makes the following diagram commute
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)
where $\mathfrak{m}_{F}$ is the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{F(X), 0}$.
Another question that naturally arises is: given two m-primary ideals $I$ and $J$ of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$, at what condition do we have the equality $\mathcal{I}_{I}=\mathcal{I}_{J}$ ? We provide a partial answer by proving that if $\mathcal{I}_{I}=\mathcal{I}_{J}$ then $I$ and $J$ have the same integral closure (Proposition 5.4).

Now, let us briefly outline the proof of Theorem A with all the tools we have introduced. The proof proceeds as follows: For each integrally closed m-primary ideal $I$ of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$, we construct a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ using Theorem C. We then demonstrate that the function $\mathcal{I}_{I}$ is determined and determines the triple $\left(\Gamma_{\pi_{I}}, L_{\pi_{I}}, P_{\pi_{I}}\right)$ introduced just before the statement of Theorem A. The key idea to establish this result relies on the use of the inner rate formula 1.17, initially proven in [BdSFP22] and generalized in [Che24a]. This formula provides us that the vector $P_{\pi_{I}}$ and the inner rates $\left(q_{v}^{I}\right)_{v \in V\left(\Gamma_{\pi_{I}}\right)}$ are equivalent data when given the vector $L_{\pi_{I}}$. Finally, by invoking Proposition 5.4 mentioned right before this paragraph, we conclude that if $I \neq J$, then $\left(\Gamma_{\pi_{I}}, L_{\pi_{I}}, P_{\pi_{I}}\right) \neq\left(\Gamma_{\pi_{J}}, L_{\pi_{J}}, P_{\pi_{J}}\right)$.

# 1. Preliminaries 

This section is dedicated to reviewing the necessary material for this paper. The definitions and results presented in Subsections 1.1 and 1.2 can be found in [BdSFP22, GR21, MM20, Mic08, Che24a], while the content of Subsections 1.3 and 1.4 is detailed in [Che24a] and [Che24b] .
1.1. Resolution of curves and surfaces. In this subsection we introduce some classical tools about resolution of singularities of curves and surfaces.

Definition 1.1 (Resolution of singularities). Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ. A resolution of $(X, 0)$ is a proper modification $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ such that $X_{\pi}$ is a smooth complex surface and the restricted function $\pi_{\left|X_{\pi}\right| E}: X_{\pi} \backslash E \longrightarrow X \backslash \operatorname{Sing}(X)$ is a biholomorphism. The curve $E=\pi^{-1}(0)$ is called the exceptional divisor. The resolution $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ is good if $E$ is a simple normal crossing divisor i.e., it has smooth compact irreducible components and the singular points of $E$ are transversal double points. Let $E_{v}$ be an irreducible component of E. A curvette of $E_{v}$ is a smooth curve germ which intersects $E_{v}$ transversely at a smooth point of $E$.

Definition 1.2 (Strict transform and total transform of a curve germ). Let $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a modification of $(X, 0)$ and let $(C, 0)$ be a curve germ in $(X, 0)$. The strict transform of $C$ by $\pi$ is the curve $C^{*}$ in $X_{\pi}$ defined as the topological closure of the set $\pi^{-1}(C \backslash\{0\})$. Let $E_{1}, E_{2}, \ldots, E_{n}$ be the irreducible components of $E$ and $h:(X, 0) \longrightarrow(\mathbb{C}, 0)$ be a holomorphic function. The total transform of $h$ by $\pi$ is the principal divisor $(h \circ \pi)$ on $X_{\pi}$, i.e.,

$$
(h \circ \pi)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i}(h) E_{i}+h^{*}
$$

where $m_{i}(h)$ is the order of vanishing of the holomorphic function ho $\pi$ on the irreducible component $E_{i}$ of $E$ and $h^{*}$ is the strict transform of the curve $h^{-1}(0)$.
Definition 1.3 (Good resolution of curve germ). Let $(C, 0)$ be a curve germ in $(X, 0)$. A proper modification $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ is a good resolution of $(X, 0)$ and $(C, 0)$ if it is a good resolution of $(X, 0)$ such that the strict transform $C^{*}$ is a disjoint union of curvettes.

Definition 1.4 (Dual graph of a resolution). The dual graph of a good resolution $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow$ $(X, 0)$ of $(X, 0)$ is the graph $\Gamma_{\pi}$ whose vertices are in bijection with the irreducible components of $E$ and such that the edges between the vertices $v$ and $v^{\prime}$ corresponding to $E_{v}$ and $E_{v^{\prime}}$ are in bijection with $E_{v} \cap E_{v^{\prime}}$, each vertex $v$ of this graph is weighted with the self intersection number $E_{v}^{2}$ and the genus $g_{v}$ of the corresponding curve $E_{v}$. We denote by $V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)$ the set of vertices of $\Gamma_{\pi}$ and $E\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)$ the set of edges. The valency of a vertex $v$ is the number $\operatorname{val}_{\Gamma_{\pi}}(v):=\left(\sum_{i \in V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right), i \neq v} E_{i}\right) \cdot E_{v}$.
1.2. Non-archimedean link. The following definitions and results can be found in [BdSFP22, Preliminaries] and [GR21, Section 2]. Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity. Denote by $\mathcal{O}=\widehat{\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}}$ the completion of the local ring of $X$ at 0 with respect to its maximal ideal.

Definition 1.5 (Semivaluation). A (rank 1) semivaluation on $\mathcal{O}$ is a map $v: \mathcal{O} \longrightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{+\infty\}$ such that, for every $f, g \in \mathcal{O}$ and every $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$

- $v(f g)=v(f)+v(g)$
- $v(f+g) \geq \min \{v(f), v(g)\}$
- $v(\lambda)= \begin{cases}+\infty & \text { if } \lambda=0 \\ 0 & \text { if } \lambda \neq 0\end{cases}$.

A valuation is a semivalutation such that 0 is the only element sent to $+\infty$.
Definition 1.6 (Evaluation of an ideal). Given an ideal $I$ of $\mathcal{O}$ and a semivaluation $v$ we define the evaluation of $I$ by $v$ to be

$$
v(I)=\inf \{v(h) \mid h \in I\}
$$

Example 1.7 (Normalized divisorial valuations). Let $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution of $(X, 0)$. Let $E_{v}$ be an irreducible component of the exceptional divisor $E$. Let $\mathfrak{m}$ be the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}$ and set $m_{v}(\mathfrak{m}):=\inf \left\{m_{v}(h) \mid h \in \mathfrak{m}\right\}$. The map

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{val}_{E_{v}}: \mathcal{O} & \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+} \cup\{+\infty\}, \\
f & \mapsto \frac{m_{v}(f)}{m_{v}(\mathfrak{m})}
\end{aligned}
$$

is a valuation on $\mathcal{O}$. We call it the divisorial valuation associated with $E_{v}$.
Example 1.8 (Normalized monomial valuations). Let $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution of $(X, 0)$. Let $p \in X_{\pi}$ be the intersecting point of two irreducible component $E_{v}$ and $E_{w}$ of the exceptional divisor $E$. Let $(x, y)$ be a local coordinate system centered at $p$ such that $x=0$ and $y=0$ are respectively the equations of $E_{v}$ and $E_{w}$. Then, for every element $f$ of $\mathcal{O}$ we have $f \circ \pi(x, y)=\sum_{i j} a_{i j} x^{i} y^{j} \in \mathbb{C} \llbracket x, y \rrbracket$. For every $t \in[0,1]$ we consider the valuation

$$
\mu_{t}(f)=\min \left\{\frac{1-t}{m_{v}(\mathfrak{m})} i+\frac{t}{m_{w}(\mathfrak{m})} j \mid a_{i j} \neq 0\right\}
$$

called Normalized monomial valuation associated with $E_{v}$ and $E_{w}$ with weight $t$. Notice that $\mu_{0}=\operatorname{val}_{E_{v}}$ and $\mu_{1}=\operatorname{val}_{E_{w}}$. Then we denote by $\left[\operatorname{val}_{E_{v}}, \operatorname{val}_{E_{w}}\right]$ the set of the normalized monomial valuations $\mu_{t}$ for $t \in[0,1]$.

Lemma 1.9 ([GR21, Subsection 2.1]). With the same notation as in Example 1.8. If $t \in[0,1]$ is a rational number then the semivaluation $\mu_{t}$ is a divisorial valuation.

Definition 1.10 (Non-archimedean link). The non-archimedean link $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ of $(X, 0)$ is the topological set

$$
\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)=\left\{v: \mathcal{O} \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+} \cup\{+\infty\} \text { semi-valuation } \mid v(\mathfrak{m})=1 \text { and } v_{\mid \mathbb{C}^{*}}=0\right\}
$$

whose topology is induced by the product topology $\left(\mathbb{R}_{+} \cup\{+\infty\}\right)^{\mathcal{O}}$.
Let $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution of $(X, 0)$. There exists an embedding

$$
i_{\pi}: \Gamma_{\pi} \longrightarrow \mathrm{NL}(X, 0)
$$

where $\Gamma_{\pi}$ is endowed with the topology such that each of its edge is homeomorphic to a real interval. There exists a continuous retraction

$$
r_{\pi}: \mathrm{NL}(X, 0) \longrightarrow \Gamma_{\pi}
$$

such that $r_{\pi} \circ i_{\pi}=\operatorname{Id}_{\Gamma_{\pi}}$. The embedding $i_{\pi}$ maps each vertex $v$ of $\Gamma_{\pi}$ to the normalized divisorial valuation associated with the component $E_{v}$, and each edge $e_{v, v^{\prime}}$ that corresponds to a point $p$ of the intersection $E_{v} \cap E_{v^{\prime}}$ to the set of normalized monomial valuations on $X_{\pi}$ at $p$. In this paper we will mostly make use of the following theorem which gives a description of the non-achimedean link in terms of dual graphs.

Theorem 1.11 (See e.g., [GR21, Theorem 2.27] and [Jon15, Theorem 7.9]). The family of the continuous retractions $\left\{r_{\pi} \mid \pi\right.$ is a good resolution of $(X, 0)\}$ induces a homeomorphism from $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ to the inverse limit of the dual graphs $\Gamma_{\pi}$

$$
\mathrm{NL}(X, 0) \cong \varliminf_{\pi} \Gamma_{\pi}
$$

Remark 1.12. It follows from Lemma 1.9 that given a good resolution $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ and two irreducible components $E_{v}$ and $E_{w}$ of $E$ the set of divisorial valuations of $\left[\mathrm{val}_{E_{v}}, \mathrm{val}_{E_{w}}\right]$ is dense in $\left[\mathrm{val}_{E_{v}}, \mathrm{val}_{E_{w}}\right]$.

Let $F:(X, 0) \longrightarrow(Y, 0)$ be a finite holomorphic map between two complex surface germ $(X, 0)$ and $(Y, 0)$. It induces a continuous map $\widetilde{F}: \mathrm{NL}(X, 0) \longrightarrow \mathrm{NL}(Y, 0)$. Indeed, we set $F^{\#}: \widetilde{\mathcal{O}_{(Y, 0)}} \longrightarrow \widetilde{\mathcal{O}_{(X, 0)}}$ defined by $F^{\#}(h)=h \circ F$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tilde{F}: \mathrm{NL}(X, 0) & \rightarrow \mathrm{NL}(Y, 0) \\
v & \mapsto \frac{v \circ F^{\#}}{v\left(\tilde{F}^{*}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{Y}\right)\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathfrak{m}_{Y}$ is the maximal ideal of the completion $\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}_{Y, 0}$. The map $\tilde{F}$ has the following properties
Proposition 1.13 ([GR21, Proposition 4.4]). The following holds for any finite holomorphic map $F:(X, 0) \longrightarrow(Y, 0)$
(i) the map $\tilde{F}$ is surjective.
(ii) every $v \in \mathrm{NL}(Y, 0)$ has at most $N$ preimages under $\tilde{F}$, where $N$ is the degree of the fields extension $\frac{\operatorname{Frac}\left(\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}_{Y}\right)}{F^{*} \operatorname{Frac}\left(\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}_{Y}\right)}$. In particular if $F$ is a finite modification then $\tilde{F}$ is one to one.
1.3. Inner-rates of a finite morphism. Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity, and let $g, f:(X, 0) \longrightarrow(\mathbb{C}, 0)$ be two holomorphic functions such that the morphism $\Phi=(g, f):(X, 0) \longrightarrow\left(\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0\right)$ is finite. The aim of this subsection is to recall the notion of inner rates associated with a finite morphism $\Phi=(g, f):(X, 0) \longrightarrow\left(\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0\right)$ as defined in [Che24b, Definition 2.2], which generalizes the inner rates of complex surface germs introduced in [BdSFP22, Definition 3.3]. We will provide the proof of the necessary Proposition 1.15 without additional comments. For more context and examples, we encourage readers to refer to the papers mentioned above.

Definition 1.14 (See e.g [KP04, Definition 0.1]). The polar curve of the morphism $\Phi$ is the curve $\Pi_{\Phi}$ defined as the topological closure of the critical locus of the finite morphism $\Phi=(g, f)$, that is

$$
\Pi_{\Phi}=\overline{\left\{x \in X \backslash\{0\} \mid d_{x} \Phi: T_{x} X \longrightarrow \overline{\mathbb{C}^{2}} \text { is non surjective }\right\}}
$$

Equivalently it can be defined as the vanishing locus of the holomorphic 2-form $\mathrm{d} g \wedge \mathrm{~d} f$.
Proposition 1.15 ([Che24b, Proposition 2.3], [Che24a, Proposition 2.4]). Let $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow$ $(X, 0)$ be a good resolution of $(X, 0)$ and let $E_{v}$ be an irreducible component of the exceptional divisor $E$. Let us denote by $\left(u_{1}, u_{2}\right)=(g, f)$ the coordinates of $\mathbb{C}^{2}$ and by d the standard hermitian metric of $\mathbb{C}^{2}$. Then, for every smooth point $p$ of $E$ in $E_{v} \backslash\left(f^{*} \cup g^{*} \cup \Pi_{\Phi}^{*}\right)$, there exists an open neighborhood $O_{p} \subset E_{v}$ of $p$ such that for every pair of curvettes $\gamma_{1}^{*}, \gamma_{2}^{*}$ of $E_{v}$ verifying:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\gamma_{1}^{*} \cap \gamma_{2}^{*}=\emptyset \\
\gamma_{i}^{*} \cap O_{p} \neq \emptyset \text { for } i=1,2
\end{array}\right.
$$

we have:

$$
\mathrm{d}\left(\gamma_{1} \cap\left\{u_{2}=\epsilon\right\}, \gamma_{2} \cap\left\{u_{2}=\epsilon\right\}\right)=\Theta\left(\epsilon^{q_{g, v}^{f}}\right), q_{g, v}^{f}:=\frac{\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}(\mathrm{~d} g \wedge \mathrm{~d} f)\right)-m_{v}(f)+1}{m_{v}(f)}
$$

where $\gamma_{1}=(\Phi \circ \pi)\left(\gamma_{1}^{*}\right), \gamma_{2}=(\Phi \circ \pi)\left(\gamma_{2}^{*}\right)$ and $\epsilon \in \mathbb{R}$.
Definition 1.16. [Che24a, Definition 2.3] We call $q_{g, v}^{f}$ the inner rate of $f$ with respect to $g$ along $E_{v}$.

Proof of Proposition 1.15. Let $p$ be a smooth point of $E_{v}$ which does not belong to the strict transforms $f^{*}, g^{*}$ and $\Pi_{\Phi}^{*}$. Let $(x, y)$ be a local system of coordinates of $X_{\pi}$ centered at $p$ such that $E_{v}$ has local equation $x=0$ and such that $(f \circ \pi)(x, y)=x^{m_{v}(f)}$. Let $U$ be the unit of $\mathbb{C}\{x, y\}$ such that $(g \circ \pi)(x, y)=x^{m_{v}(g)} U(x, y)$. We can write

$$
U(x, y)=\sum_{i \geq 0} a_{i 0} x^{i}+\sum_{j \geq 1} y^{j} \sum_{i \geq 0} a_{i j} x^{i}
$$

Since $\Phi$ is a finite morphism the set $\left\{i \geq 0 \mid \exists j>0, a_{i j} \neq 0\right\}$. is non empty. Let $k$ be its minimal element. Then,

$$
U(x, y)=g_{0}(x)+x^{k} \sum_{j \geq 1} y^{j} g_{j}(x)
$$

where $g_{0}(x)=\sum_{i \geq 0} a_{i 0} x^{i}$ and $g_{j}(x)=\sum_{i \geq 0} a_{i j} x^{i-k}$. Note that the set $\left\{j>0 \mid g_{j}(0) \neq 0\right\}$ is non empty.

Setting $q_{p}:=\frac{m_{v}(g)+k}{m_{v}(g)}$, we then have:

$$
(g \circ \pi)(x, y)=x^{m_{v}(g)} g_{0}(x)+x^{q_{p} m_{v}(g)} \sum_{j \geq 1} y^{j} g_{j}(x)
$$

Let $\gamma_{1}^{*}$ and $\gamma_{2}^{*}$ be two curvettes of $E_{v}$ parametrized respectively by

$$
t \mapsto\left(t, \alpha+t h_{1}(t)\right), t \mapsto\left(t, \beta+t h_{2}(t)\right), \alpha, \beta \in \mathbb{C}
$$

where $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ are convergent power series. The curves $\gamma_{1}=(\Phi \circ \pi)\left(\gamma_{1}^{*}\right)$ and $\gamma_{2}=(\Phi \circ \pi)\left(\gamma_{2}^{*}\right)$ are then parametrized respectively by

$$
t \mapsto\left(t^{m_{v}(g)} g_{0}(t)+t^{q_{p} m_{v}(g)} \sum_{j \geq 1}\left(\alpha+t h_{1}(t)\right)^{j} g_{j}(t), t^{m_{v}(f)}\right)
$$

and

$$
t \mapsto\left(t^{m_{v}(g)} g_{0}(t)+t^{q_{p} m_{v}(g)} \sum_{j \geq 1}\left(\beta+t h_{2}(t)\right)^{j} g_{j}(t), t^{m_{v}(f)}\right)
$$

Therefore, for $\epsilon>0$, we have

$$
\mathrm{d}\left(\gamma_{1} \cap\left\{u_{2}=\epsilon\right\}, \gamma_{2} \cap\left\{u_{2}=\epsilon\right\}\right)=\left|\epsilon^{\frac{q_{p} m_{v}(g)}{m_{v}(f)}}\right| H(\epsilon)
$$

where

$$
H(\epsilon)=\left|\sum_{j \geq 1}\left(\left(\alpha+\epsilon^{\frac{1}{m_{v}(f)}} h_{1}\left(\epsilon^{\frac{1}{m_{v}(f)}}\right)\right)^{j}-\left(\beta+\epsilon^{\frac{1}{m_{v}(f)}} h_{2}\left(\epsilon^{\frac{1}{m_{v}(f)}}\right)\right)^{j}\right) g_{j}\left(\epsilon^{\frac{1}{m_{v}(f)}}\right)\right|
$$

We need to prove that

$$
H(0)=\left|\sum_{j \geq 1}\left(\alpha^{j}-\beta^{j}\right) g_{j}(0)\right|
$$

does not vanish when $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are distinct and in a small enough neighborhood of the origin of $\mathbb{C}$. Let $j_{0}>0$ be the minimal element of the set $\left\{j>0 \mid g_{j}(0) \neq 0\right\}$ then

$$
H(0)=\left|\left(\alpha^{j_{0}}-\beta^{j_{0}}\right) g_{j_{0}}(0)+\sum_{j \geq 1, j \neq j_{0}}\left(\alpha^{j}-\beta^{j}\right) g_{j}(0)\right|
$$

Now, let us prove that $j_{0}=1$. Let us compute in the coordinates $(x, y)$ the equation of the total transform of the polar curve. The jacobian matrix of $\Phi \circ \pi$ is

$$
\operatorname{Jac}(\Phi \circ \pi)(x, y)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
* & x^{q_{p} m_{v}(g)}\left(g_{1}(x)+2 y g_{2}(x)+\ldots\right) \\
m_{v}(f) x^{m_{v}(f)-1} & 0
\end{array}\right)
$$

then $\operatorname{Det}(\operatorname{Jac}(\Phi \circ \pi)(x, y))=m_{v}(f) x^{q_{p} m_{v}(g)+m_{v}(f)-1}\left(g_{1}(x)+2 y g_{2}(x)+\ldots\right)=0$ is the equation of the total transform of $\Pi_{\Phi}$. Since $g_{j_{0}}(0) \neq 0$ it follows that the equation of the strict transform of the polar curve $\Pi_{\Phi}^{*}$ is

$$
\sum_{j \geq 1} j y^{j-1} g_{j}(x)=0
$$

By hypothesis $p \notin \Pi_{\Phi}^{*}$ which means that $g_{1}(0) \neq 0$ and then $j_{0}=1$. Thus

$$
H(0)=\left|(\alpha-\beta) g_{1}(0)+\sum_{j>1}\left(\alpha^{j}-\beta^{j}\right) g_{j}(0)\right|
$$

If $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are distinct and in a small enough neighborhood of $0 \in \mathbb{C}$ we have $H(0) \neq 0$. With this, we can conclude that there exists a neighborhood $O_{p}$ of $p$ such that for every curvettes satisfying $(2.1)$

$$
\mathrm{d}\left(\gamma_{1} \cap\left\{u_{2}=\epsilon\right\}, \gamma_{2} \cap\left\{u_{2}=\epsilon\right\}\right)=\left|\epsilon^{\frac{q_{p} m_{v}(g)}{m_{v}(f)}}\right| H(\epsilon)=\Theta\left(\epsilon^{\frac{m_{v}(g) q_{p}}{m_{v}(f)}}\right)
$$

Now we will see that the number $\frac{q_{p} m_{v}(g)}{m_{v}(f)}$ does not depend of the point $p$.
Let us consider the holomorphic 2 -form $\Omega=\pi^{*}(\mathrm{~d} g \wedge \mathrm{~d} f)$ on $X_{\pi}$. In the neighborhood of $p$, a direct computation shows that the holomorphic 2 -form $\Omega$ is given in the coordinates $(x, y)$ by:

$$
\Omega=-m_{v}(f) x^{q_{p} m_{v}(g)+m_{v}(f)-1} \sum_{j \geq 1} j y^{j-1} g_{j}(x) \mathrm{d} x \wedge \mathrm{~d} y
$$

It follows that the order of vanishing of the holomorphic 2-form $\Omega$ along the irreducible component $E_{v}$ is

$$
\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}(\mathrm{~d} g \wedge \mathrm{~d} f)\right)=q_{p} m_{v}(g)+m_{v}(f)-1
$$

The number $\frac{q_{p} m_{v}(g)}{m_{v}(f)}$ is then independant of the point $p$ and is equal to

$$
\frac{q_{p} m_{v}(g)}{m_{v}(f)}=q_{g, v}^{f}:=\frac{\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}(\mathrm{~d} g \wedge \mathrm{~d} f)\right)-m_{v}(f)+1}{m_{v}(f)}
$$

1.4. Inner rates formula. Let us recall the inner rates formula from [Che24a, Theorem 3.1], which generalizes a previous result from [BdSFP22, Theorem 4.3]. This formula will play a key role in the proof of Theorem A mentioned in the introduction. In this subsection, we will provide a proof of this formula to ensure that the paper is as self-contained as possible. For those seeking more details, we encourage you to refer to the previously mentioned papers.

Theorem 1.17 (The inner rates formula). Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity and let $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution of $(X, 0)$. Let $g, f:(X, 0) \longrightarrow(\mathbb{C}, 0)$ be two holomorphic functions on $X$ such that the morphism $\Phi=(g, f):(X, 0) \longrightarrow\left(\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0\right)$ is finite. Let $M_{\pi}=\left(E_{v_{i}} \cdot E_{v_{j}}\right)_{i, j \in\{1,2, \ldots, n\}}$ be the intersection matrix of the dual graph $\Gamma_{\pi}$, $a_{g, \pi}^{f}:=\left(m_{v_{1}}(f) q_{g, v_{1}}^{f}, \ldots, m_{v_{n}}(f) q_{g, v_{n}}^{f}\right), K_{\pi}:=\left(\operatorname{val}_{\Gamma_{\pi}}\left(v_{1}\right)+2 g_{v_{1}}-2, \ldots, \operatorname{val}_{\Gamma_{\pi}}\left(v_{n}\right)+2 g_{v_{n}}-2\right), F_{\pi}=$ $\left(f^{*} \cdot E_{v_{1}}, \ldots, f^{*} \cdot E_{v_{n}}\right)$ be the $F$-vector and $P_{\pi}=\left(\Pi_{\Phi}^{*} \cdot E_{v_{1}}, \ldots, \Pi_{\Phi}^{*} \cdot E_{v_{n}}\right)$ be the polar vector or $\mathcal{P}$-vector. Then we have:

$$
M_{\pi} \cdot a_{g, \pi}^{f}=\underline{K_{\pi}}+\underline{F_{\pi}}-\underline{P_{\pi}}
$$

Equivalently, for each irreducible component $E_{v}$ of $E$ we have the following:

$$
\left(\sum_{i \in V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)} m_{i}(f) q_{g, i}^{f} E_{i}\right) \cdot E_{v}=\operatorname{val}_{\Gamma_{\pi}}(v)+f^{*} \cdot E_{v}-\Pi_{\Phi}^{*} \cdot E_{v}+2 g_{v}-2
$$

Let us introduce the required tool in order to prove Theorem 1.17.
Definition 1.18 (See e.g [Sha13, Chapter 3. Subsection 6.3]). Let $S$ be a smooth complex surface. The canonical divisor of $S$, denoted $K_{S}$, is the divisor $K_{\Omega}$ associated to any meromorphic 2form $\Omega$ defined on $S$. It is well defined up to linear equivalence i.e., for any pair of 2-forms $\Omega$ and $\Omega^{\prime}$ of $S$ there exists a meromorphic function $h$ on $S$ such that

$$
K_{\Omega}=(h)+K_{\Omega^{\prime}}
$$

where $K_{\Omega}$ and $K_{\Omega^{\prime}}$ are respectively the divisors associated to the 2 -forms $\Omega$ and $\Omega^{\prime}$.

Theorem 1.19 (Adjunction formula, see e.g [Sha13, Chapter 4. Subsection 2.3]). Let $S$ be a complex surface and $C \subset S$ be a compact Riemann surface embedded in $S$. Then

$$
\left(K_{S}+C\right) \cdot C=2 g_{C}-2, \quad \text { where } g_{C} \text { is the genus of } C
$$

Proof of Theorem 1.17. Let us consider the holomorphic 2 -form $\Omega:=\pi^{*}(\mathrm{~d} g \wedge \mathrm{~d} f)$ defined on the smooth complex surface $X_{\pi}$. Since $\pi_{X_{\pi} \backslash E}: X_{\pi} \backslash E \longrightarrow X \backslash 0$ is an isomorphism, the vanishing locus of $\Omega$ is $E \cup \Pi_{\Phi}^{*}$. The associated canonical divisor of $X_{\pi}$ is given by

$$
K_{\Omega}=\sum_{v_{i} \in V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)} \operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v_{i}}}\left(\pi^{*}(\mathrm{~d} g \wedge \mathrm{~d} f)\right) E_{v_{i}}+\Pi_{\Phi}^{*}
$$

By definition of the inner rates we can rewrite the divisor $K_{\Omega}$ as follows

$$
K_{\Omega}=\sum_{v_{i} \in V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)}\left(m_{v_{i}}(f) q_{g, v_{i}}^{f}+m_{v_{i}}(f)-1\right) E_{v_{i}}+\Pi_{\Phi}^{*}
$$

We now apply the adjunction formula 1.19 to the compact Riemann surface $E_{v}$

$$
\left(K_{\Omega}+E_{v}\right) \cdot E_{v}=2 g_{v}-2
$$

Combining equations (3) and (4), we obtain:

$$
\sum_{v_{i} \in V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)} q_{g, v_{i}}^{f} m_{v_{i}}(f) E_{v_{i}} \cdot E_{v}+\sum_{v_{i} \in V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)} m_{v_{i}}(f) E_{v_{i}} \cdot E_{v}-\sum_{v_{i} \in V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right), v_{i} \neq v} E_{v_{i}} \cdot E_{v}+\Pi_{\Phi}^{*} \cdot E_{v}=2 g_{v}-2
$$

Recall that we denote by $(f \circ \pi)$ the principal divisor associated with the holomorphic function $f \circ \pi$.

Finally, we have the following formula which comes from the fact that $(f \circ \pi) \cdot E_{v}=0$ :

$$
\left(\sum_{v_{i} \in V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)} m_{v_{i}}(f) E_{v_{i}} \cdot E_{v}\right)=\left(-f^{*} \cdot E_{v}\right)
$$

Replacing this in Equation 5, we get the desired equality:

$$
\sum_{v_{i} \in V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)} q_{g, v_{i}}^{f} m_{v_{i}}(f) E_{v_{i}} \cdot E_{v}=\operatorname{val}_{\Gamma_{\pi}}(v)+f^{*} \cdot E_{v}-\Pi_{\Phi}^{*} \cdot E_{v}+2 g_{v}-2
$$

# 2. INNER RATES OF PRIMARY IDEALS 

2.1. Definition of the inner rates of an m-primary ideal. Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity. Let $I$ be an m-primary ideal of the local ring $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$ associated with $(X, 0)$. This means that there exists a positive natural number $n$ such that $\mathfrak{m}^{n} \subset I$, where $\mathfrak{m}$ is the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. The aim of this section is to study a notion of inner rates with respect to the ideal $I$ :

Definition 2.1. Let $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution of $(X, 0)$ and let $E_{v}$ be an irreducible component of $E$. We set

$$
m_{v}(I):=\inf \left\{m_{v}(h) \mid h \in I\right\}
$$

and

$$
\nu_{v}(I):=\inf \left\{\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} h_{1} \wedge \mathrm{~d} h_{2}\right)\right) \mid h_{1}, h_{2} \in I\right\}
$$

We call the rational number

$$
q_{v}^{I}:=\frac{\nu_{v}(I)-m_{v}(I)+1}{m_{v}(I)}
$$

the inner rate of the ideal $I$ along $E_{v}$.

The motivation behind this definition lies in the existence (Proposition 2.15) of a suitable system of generators $\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ for the ideal $I$ (called precomplete) which verifies the following condition. There exists a Zariski open set $V_{I}^{\pi}$ of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ such that for every good resolution $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$, every irreducible component $E_{v}$ of $E$ and every element $\left(\alpha=\left[\alpha_{1}: \cdots: \alpha_{k}\right], \beta=\left[\beta_{1}: \cdots: \beta_{k}\right]\right)$ of $V_{I}^{\pi}$ we have

$$
m_{v}\left(F_{\alpha}\right)=m_{v}(I)=m_{v}\left(F_{\beta}\right)
$$

and

$$
\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} F_{\alpha} \wedge \mathrm{d} F_{\beta}\right)\right)=\nu_{v}(I)
$$

where $F_{\alpha}=\sum_{i=1}^{k} \alpha_{i} f_{i}$ and $F_{\beta}=\sum_{i=1}^{k} \beta_{i} f_{i}$.
It follows from Proposition 1.15 that the inner rates

$$
q_{F_{\alpha}, v}^{F_{\beta}}=\frac{\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} F_{\alpha} \wedge \mathrm{d} F_{\beta}\right)\right)-m_{v}\left(F_{\beta}\right)+1}{m_{v}\left(F_{\beta}\right)}
$$

associated to the morphism $\Phi_{\alpha, \beta}=\left(F_{\alpha}, F_{\beta}\right):(X, 0) \longrightarrow\left(\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0\right)$ does not depend on the choice of $(\alpha, \beta)$ in $V_{I}^{\pi}$ and is equal to $q_{v}^{I}$. The proof of Proposition 2.15 will need the classical notion of blow-up of ideals which we recall now.
2.2. Preliminaries on the blow-up of an ideal. Let $F=\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ be a set of generators for the m-primary ideal $I$. Consider the map

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nu_{F}: X \backslash\{0\} & \rightarrow \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \\
p & \mapsto\left[f_{1}(p): f_{2}(p): \cdots: f_{k}(p)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The map $\nu_{F}$ is well defined because the ideal $I$ is m -primary, thus its generators cannot vanish simultaneously outside of 0 . Let

$$
X_{F}:=\overline{\operatorname{Graph}\left(\nu_{F}\right)}=\overline{\left\{\left(p,\left[f_{1}(p): \cdots: f_{k}(p)\right]\right) \mid p \in X \backslash 0\right\}} \subset X \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)
$$

and consider the modification

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{BL}_{F}:\left(X_{F}, E_{F}\right) & \rightarrow(X, 0) \\
(p, v) & \mapsto p
\end{aligned}
$$

where $E_{F}=\mathrm{BL}_{F}^{-1}(0)$. The modification $\mathrm{BL}_{F}$ does not depend on the choice of the generators $F=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ in the following sense:

Proposition 2.2. Let $G=\left(g_{1}, g_{2}, \ldots, g_{s}\right)$ be another set of generators for $I$. There exists a unique isomorphism $h:\left(X_{G}, E_{G}\right) \longrightarrow\left(X_{F}, E_{F}\right)$ such that the following diagram commutes:
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Definition 2.3. The map $\mathrm{BL}_{F}$ is denoted $\mathrm{BL}_{I}:\left(X_{I}, E_{I}\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ and is called the blow-up of the ideal $I$.

Let us recall the universal property of the blow-up of an ideal.
Proposition 2.4 ([Hir64] or see [PT20, Proposition 10.2.2]). The blow-up $\mathrm{BL}_{I}:\left(X_{I}, E_{I}\right) \longrightarrow$ $(X, 0)$ of the ideal $I$ is the unique modification such that:
(i) The ideal sheaf $I . \mathcal{O}_{X_{I}}:=\mathrm{BL}_{I}^{*}(I) \otimes \mathcal{O}_{X_{I}}$ is locally principal.
(ii) For every modification $\phi: T \longrightarrow X$ such that $I . \mathcal{O}_{T}$ is locally principal, there is a unique factorization $r: T \longrightarrow X_{I}$ such that $\phi=\mathrm{BL}_{I} \circ r$.

Throughout this paper we will adopt the following notations.
Notation 2.5. Let $F=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ be a system of generators of the ideal $I$ and $\alpha:=\left[\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2}, \ldots, \alpha_{k}\right] \in$ $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$. We denote by $F_{\alpha}$ the function $\sum_{i=1}^{k} \alpha_{i} f_{i}$. Let $\Omega_{F}$ be the Zariski open set of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ such that $F_{\alpha}^{-1}(0)$ is a curve germ. We denote by $L_{F}$ the family of curve germs $\left\{F_{\alpha}^{-1}(0)\right\}_{\alpha \in \Omega_{F}}$.

Let us recall the notion of basepoints of a family of curves with respect to a modification.
Definition 2.6. Let $C=\left\{C_{\alpha}\right\}_{\alpha \in \Omega}$ be a family of curves on $(X, 0)$ parametrized by an open Zariski set $\Omega$ of some projective space. Let $\sigma:(Y, Z) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a modification. We say that a point $p$ in $Z$ is a basepoint for the family $C$ if $p \in C_{\alpha}^{*}$ for every $\alpha \in \Omega^{\prime}$, where $\Omega^{\prime}$ is an open Zariski set of $\Omega$ and $C_{\alpha}^{*}$ is the strict transform of $C_{\alpha}$ by $\sigma$.

In the following proposition we give an equivalent property to Point (i) of Proposition 2.4 in terms of the basepoints of a family of curves.

Proposition 2.7. Let $\sigma:(Y, Z) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a modification and $I$ be a m-primary ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. Let $F=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ be a system of generators for $I$. Then the following assertions are equivalent
(i) The ideal sheaf $I . \mathcal{O}_{Y}:=\sigma^{*}(I) \otimes \mathcal{O}_{Y}$ is locally principal.
(ii) The modification $\sigma$ has no basepoint for the family $L_{F}$.

Proof. We first prove that (i) implies (ii)
Let $\bar{p}$ be a point of $Z$ and assume that $\left(I . \mathcal{O}_{Y}\right)_{p}$ is principal i.e, there exists a section $s_{p}=h \circ \sigma$ with $h \in I$ which generates the ideal $\left(I . \mathcal{O}_{Y}\right)_{p}$. We prove that the point $p$ cannot be a basepoint for the family $L_{F}$. Let $h^{*}$ be the strict transform of $h^{-1}(0)$ by $\sigma$ and let us suppose it passes through the point $p$. It follows that every curve $F_{\alpha}^{*}, \alpha \in \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$, where $F_{\alpha}^{-1}(0) \in L_{F}$, contains the curve $h^{*}$ because $F_{\alpha} \circ \sigma=a_{\alpha} s_{p}, a_{\alpha} \in \mathcal{O}_{Y, p}$. It implies that $h^{-1}(0) \subset F_{\alpha}^{-1}(0), \forall \alpha \in \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ and this is absurd because it would mean that the ideal $I$ is generated by $h$ and it contradicts the fact that $I$ is m -primary. It follows that the element $s_{p}$ vanishes only on $Z$. Since $F=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ is a system of generators for $I$ there exists $i_{p}:=1, \ldots, k$ such that $f_{i_{p}} \circ \sigma$ vanishes only on $Z$ in a small enough neighborhood of $p$. Knowing this, we can conclude the existence of a Zariski open set $O_{p}$ of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ such that the functions $\alpha_{i_{p}} f_{i_{p}} \circ \sigma+\sum_{i=1, i \neq i_{p}}^{k} \alpha_{i} f_{i} \circ \sigma$ do not vanish outside of $Z$ when restricted to a small enough neighborhood of $p$ for all $\left[\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{i_{p}}, \ldots, \alpha_{k}\right] \in O_{p}$. It means that $p$ is indeed not a basepoint for the family $L_{F}$.

Let us prove that (ii) implies (i).
Let $p$ be a point of $Z$ such that the germ $(Z, p)$ is irreducible. By assumption, there exists a Zariski open set $O_{p}$ of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ such that $F_{\alpha}^{*}$ does not pass through $p$ for all $\alpha$ in $O_{p}$. It follows that $F_{\alpha} \circ \sigma$ does not vanish outside of $Z$ when restricted to a small enough neighborhood of $p$. In particular, the vanishing set of the ideal $\left(I . \mathcal{O}_{Y}\right)_{p}$ is the germ of curve $(Z, p)$. Let $s_{p}$ be an element of $\mathcal{O}_{Y, p}$ which generates the vanishing ideal $I_{(Z, p)}$ of the germ $(Z, p)$. Let $m$ be the maximal integer such that $s_{p}^{m}$ divides $f_{i} \circ \sigma \in\left(I . \mathcal{O}_{Y}\right)_{p}$ for all $i:=1, \ldots, k$. Let $U_{p}$ be the Zariski open set of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ such that $F_{\alpha} \circ \sigma=s_{p}^{m} h_{\alpha}, h_{\alpha} \in \mathcal{O}_{Y, p}$ and $s_{p}$ does not divide $h_{\alpha}$ for all $\alpha \in U_{p}$. Then, for all $\alpha \in O_{p} \cap U_{p}$ we have $F_{\alpha} \circ \sigma=s_{p}^{m} u_{\alpha}$ where $u_{\alpha}$ is a unit of $\mathcal{O}_{Y, p}$ because $F_{\alpha} \circ \sigma$ do not vanish outside of $Z$. It follows that $s_{p}^{m}$ is an element of $\left(I . \mathcal{O}_{Y}\right)_{p}$ and thus generates it. Indeed, let $g \in\left(I . \mathcal{O}_{Y}\right)_{p}$ then $g=\sum_{i=1}^{k} g_{i} f_{i} \circ \sigma, g_{i} \in \mathcal{O}_{Y, p}$ and $s_{p}^{m}$ divides every element $f_{i} \circ \sigma$. Similar arguments work if $p$ is a point such that $(Z, p)$ is not irreducible.
2.3. Precomplete systems of generators. The aim of this subsection is to introduce the notion of precomplete system of generators of an ideal and to prove Proposition 2.15 announced in Subsection 2.1. The proof needs several preliminary lemmas

Lemma 2.8. Let $F=\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ be a set of generators for $I$ and $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution of $(X, 0)$. There exists a Zariski open set $U_{I}^{\pi}$ of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ such that for any irreducible component $E_{v}$ of $E$ and any element $\alpha$ of $U_{I}^{\pi}$ we have

$$
m_{v}\left(F_{\alpha}\right)=m_{v}(I)
$$

Proof. Let $p$ be a smooth point of $E_{v}$ and $(x, y)$ be a local system of coordinates of $X_{\pi}$ centered at $p$ such that $E_{v}$ has local equation $x=0$. In this setting we have $\left(f_{i} \circ \pi\right)(x, y)=x^{m_{v}\left(f_{i}\right)} \phi_{i}(x, y), 1 \leq$ $i \leq k$, where $\phi_{i}$ is an element of $\mathbb{C}\{x, y\}$ such that $\phi_{i}(0, y) \neq 0$. For every $\alpha$ in $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ we have

$$
\left(F_{\alpha} \circ \pi\right)(x, y)=\sum_{i=1}^{k} \alpha_{i} x^{m_{v}\left(f_{i}\right)} \phi_{i}(x, y)
$$

Denote by $i_{0}$ the element of $\{1, \ldots, k\}$ such that $m_{v}\left(f_{i_{0}}\right):=\min \left\{m_{v}\left(f_{i}\right) \mid 1 \leq i \leq k\right\}$, then

$$
\left(F_{\alpha} \circ \pi\right)(x, y)=x^{m_{v}\left(f_{i_{0}}\right)}\left(\alpha_{i_{0}} \phi_{i_{0}}(x, y)+\sum_{i \neq i_{0}} \alpha_{i} x^{m_{v}\left(f_{i}\right)-m_{v}\left(f_{i_{0}}\right)} \phi_{i}(x, y)\right)
$$

It follows that there exists a Zariski open set $U_{I}^{\pi}$ of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ such that

$$
m_{v}\left(F_{\alpha}\right)=m_{v}\left(f_{i_{0}}\right), \forall \alpha \in U_{I}^{\pi}
$$

Now, let $f$ be an element of $I$ such that $m_{v}(f)=m_{v}(I)$. Since $F=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ is a set of generators of $I$ then there exists $g_{1}, g_{2}, \ldots, g_{k}$ elements of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$ such that

$$
f=\sum_{i=1}^{k} g_{i} f_{i}
$$

In the local coordinates $(x, y)$ we have

$$
(f \circ \pi)(x, y)=x^{m_{v}\left(f_{i_{0}}\right)}\left(\left(g_{i_{0}} \circ \pi\right)(x, y) \phi_{i_{0}}(x, y)+\sum_{i \neq i_{0}} g_{i} \circ \pi(x, y) x^{m_{v}\left(f_{i}\right)-m_{v}\left(f_{i_{0}}\right)} \phi_{i}(x, y)\right)
$$

It is then obvious that $m_{v}(f)=m_{v}\left(f_{i_{0}}\right)$ and it implies that $m_{v}\left(F_{\alpha}\right)=m_{v}(I)$ for every $\alpha$ in $U_{I}^{\pi}$.
Let $\Omega_{X}^{2}$ be the sheaf of $\mathcal{O}_{X}$-modules of holomorphic 2-forms on $X$. Let $\Omega_{I}^{2}$ be the submodule of $\Omega_{X, 0}^{2}$ generated by the set $\{\mathrm{d} g \wedge \mathrm{~d} f \mid g, f \in I\}$. The following definition seems to be new:
Definition 2.9. A system of generators $F=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ for $I$ is precomplete if the set

$$
\left\{\mathrm{d} f_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} f_{j} \mid i, j \in\{1, \ldots, k\}\right\}
$$

generates $\Omega_{I}^{2}$.
There exists a precomplete system of generators for $I$ because the $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$-module $\Omega_{X, 0}^{2}$ is finitely generated and noetherian, so the submodule $\Omega_{I}^{2}$ is finitely generated. In the following example we see that a system of generators of $I$ is not necessarily precomplete.
Example 2.10. Consider the m-primary ideal $I=\left(x^{2}, y^{2}\right)$ of $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0}$. The set of generators $\left(x^{2}, y^{2}\right)$ is not precomplete. Indeed, let $g_{1}, g_{2}, h_{1}, h_{2}$ be arbitrary elements of $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0}$ and consider the elements $g=x^{2} g_{1}+y^{2} g_{2}$ and $h=x^{2} h_{1}+y^{2} h_{2}$ of $I$. We have

$$
\mathrm{d} g \wedge \mathrm{~d} h=\left(x^{3}(*)+x y(*)+y^{3}(*)\right) \mathrm{d} x \wedge \mathrm{~d} y
$$

In particular, take $g_{1}=\frac{1}{2}, h_{1}=y$ and $g_{2}=h_{2}=0$ then the element $\mathrm{d} g \wedge \mathrm{~d} h=x^{3} \mathrm{~d} x \wedge \mathrm{~d} y$ cannot be generated by $\mathrm{d}\left(x^{2}\right) \wedge \mathrm{d}\left(y^{2}\right)=4 x y \mathrm{~d} x \wedge \mathrm{~d} y$. On the other hand, the system of generators $\left(x^{2}, y^{2}, x y^{2}, x^{2} y\right)$ is precomplete for the ideal I. Indeed, by Equation (6) the holomorphic 2-forms

$$
\mathrm{d}\left(x^{2}\right) \wedge \mathrm{d}\left(x^{2} y\right)=2 x^{3} \mathrm{~d} x \wedge \mathrm{~d} y, \quad \mathrm{~d}\left(x^{2}\right) \wedge \mathrm{d}\left(y^{2}\right)=4 x y \mathrm{~d} x \wedge \mathrm{~d} y
$$

$$
\mathrm{d}\left(x y^{2}\right) \wedge \mathrm{d}\left(y^{2}\right)=2 y^{3} \mathrm{~d} x \wedge \mathrm{~d} y
$$

do generate the $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0}$-module $\Omega_{I}^{2}$.
Lemma 2.11. Let $F=\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ be a precomplete system of generators of $I$ and $\pi$ : $\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution of $(X, 0)$. There exists a Zariski open set $W_{I}^{\pi}$ of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times$ $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ such that for any irreducible component $E_{v}$ of $E$ and any element $(\alpha, \beta)$ of $W_{I}^{\pi}$ we have

$$
\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} F_{\alpha} \wedge \mathrm{d} F_{\beta}\right)\right)=\nu_{v}(I)
$$

Proof. Let $p$ be a smooth point of $E_{v}$ and $(x, y)$ be a local system of coordinates of $X_{\pi}$ centered at $p$ such that $E_{v}$ has local equation $x=0$. In this setting we have for every $i, j \in\{1, \ldots, k\}, i \neq j$ integers $m_{v}(i, j)$ such that

$$
\pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} f_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} f_{j}\right)(x, y)=x^{m_{v}(i, j)} \phi_{i j}(x, y) \mathrm{d} x \wedge \mathrm{~d} y
$$

where $\phi_{i j}$ is an element of $\mathbb{C}\{x, y\}$ such that $\phi_{i j}(0, y) \neq 0$. For every $\alpha, \beta$ in $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ we have

$$
\pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} F_{\alpha} \wedge \mathrm{d} F_{\beta}\right)=\sum_{i \neq j} \alpha_{i} \beta_{j} x^{m_{v}(i, j)} \phi_{i j}(x, y) d x \wedge d y
$$

Let $i_{0}, j_{0} \in\{1, \ldots, k\}$ such that $m_{v}\left(i_{0}, j_{0}\right)=\min \left\{m_{v}(i, j) \mid 1 \leq i, j \leq k\right\}$. By similar arguments of the proof of Lemma 2.8 we get the existence of a Zariski open set $W_{I}^{\pi}$ of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ such that

$$
\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}\left(d F_{\alpha} \wedge d F_{\beta}\right)\right)=m_{v}\left(i_{0}, j_{0}\right), \forall(\alpha, \beta) \in W_{I}^{\pi}
$$

Let $f, g$ be two elements of $I$ such that

$$
\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}(d f \wedge d g)\right)=\nu_{v}(I)
$$

By hypothesis the set $\left\{\mathrm{d} f_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} f_{j}\right\}_{1 \leq i, j \leq k}$ generates the $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$-module $\Omega_{I}^{2}$. Then, there exist elements $\left\{\psi_{i j}\right\}_{1 \leq i, j \leq k}$ of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$ such that

$$
\mathrm{d} f \wedge \mathrm{~d} g=\sum_{1 \leq i, j \leq k} \psi_{i j} \mathrm{~d} f_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} f_{j}
$$

This implies that

$$
\pi^{*}(\mathrm{~d} f \wedge \mathrm{~d} g)=\sum_{1 \leq i, j \leq k}\left(\psi_{i j} \circ \pi\right) \pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} f_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} f_{j}\right)
$$

It follows that $m_{v}\left(i_{0}, j_{0}\right)$ is equal to $\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}(\mathrm{~d} f \wedge \mathrm{~d} g)\right)=\nu_{v}(I)$ which implies that $\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} F_{\alpha} \wedge\right.\right.$ $\left.\left.\mathrm{d} F_{\beta}\right)\right)=\nu_{v}(I)$ for every $(\alpha, \beta)$ in $W_{I}^{\pi}$.

Until the end of this paper we use the following notations
Notation 2.12. To a precomplete system of generators $F=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ for $I$ we associate the family of curves $\Pi_{F}:=\left\{\Pi_{\alpha \beta}\right\}_{(\alpha, \beta) \in O_{F}}$ where $O_{F}$ is the Zariski open set of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ such that the morphism $\Phi_{\alpha \beta}=\left(F_{\alpha}, F_{\beta}\right):(X, 0) \longrightarrow\left(\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0\right)$ is finite for every $(\alpha, \beta)$ in $O_{F}$ and $\Pi_{\alpha \beta}$ is the polar curve of the morphism $\Phi_{\alpha, \beta}$.

Lemma 2.13. There exists a good resolution $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ such that for any precomplete system of generators $F=\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ of I the modification $\pi$ has no basepoints for the family $\Pi_{F}$.

Definition 2.14. We call the minimal good resolution as in Lemma 2.13 the principalization of the $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$-module $\Omega_{I}^{2}$.

Proof of Lemma 2.13. Let $F=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ be a precomplete system of generators for $I$. Let us first prove that there exists a good resolution of $(X, 0)$ which has no basepoint for the family $\Pi_{F}$. Let $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution and $E_{v}$ be an irreducible component of $E$.

Let $p$ be a smooth point of $E_{v}$ and $(x, y)$ be a local system of coordinates of $X_{\pi}$ centered at $p$ such that $E_{v}$ has local equation $x=0$. We use again the notations of Lemma 2.11

$$
\pi^{*}\left(d f_{i} \wedge d f_{j}\right)(x, y)=x^{m_{v}(i, j)} \phi_{i j}(x, y) d x \wedge d y
$$

where $\phi_{i j}$ is an element of $\mathbb{C}\{x, y\}$ such that $\phi_{i j}(0, y) \neq 0$. Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be two elements of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$. We have

$$
\pi^{*}\left(d F_{\alpha} \wedge d F_{\beta}\right)=\sum_{i \neq j} \alpha_{i} \beta_{j} x^{m_{v}(i, j)} \phi_{i j}(x, y) d x \wedge d y
$$

By Lemma 2.11 there exists a Zariski open set $W_{I}^{\pi}$ such that

$$
\pi^{*}\left(d F_{\alpha} \wedge d F_{\beta}\right)=x^{\nu_{v}(I)} S_{\alpha \beta}(x, y) d x \wedge d y, \text { and } S_{\alpha \beta}(0, y) \neq 0 \forall(\alpha, \beta) \in W_{I}^{\pi}
$$

where $S_{\alpha \beta}(x, y)=\sum_{i \neq j} \alpha_{i} \beta_{j} x^{m_{v}(i, j)-\nu_{v}(I)} \phi_{i j}(x, y)$. By definition $S_{\alpha \beta}(x, y)=0$ is the local equation of the strict transform of the curve $\Pi_{\alpha \beta}$ by $\pi$.

Let us assume that $p$ is a basepoint for the family of curves $\Pi_{F}$. If there exists $\left(\alpha_{0}, \beta_{0}\right)$ in $W_{I}^{\pi}$ such that $\Pi_{\alpha_{0} \beta_{0}}^{*}$ does not pass through $p$ then $S_{\alpha_{0} \beta_{0}}$ is a unit of $\mathbb{C}\{x, y\}$. It implies that for every $(\alpha, \beta)$ in $W_{I}^{\pi}$ there exists $h_{\alpha \beta}$ in $\mathbb{C}\{x, y\}$ such that

$$
\pi^{*}\left(d F_{\alpha} \wedge d F_{\beta}\right)=h_{\alpha \beta} \pi^{*}\left(d F_{\alpha_{0}} \wedge d F_{\beta_{0}}\right)
$$

For any $(\alpha, \beta)$ in $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ denote by $\omega_{\alpha \beta}$ the holomorphic 2 -form $\pi^{*}\left(d F_{\alpha} \wedge d F_{\beta}\right)$. A direct computation shows that for any elements $t_{1}, t_{2}$ of $\mathbb{C}$ we have the equality

$$
\omega_{\alpha_{0}+t_{1} \alpha, \beta_{0}+t_{2} \beta}=\omega_{\alpha_{0}, \beta_{0}}\left(1+t_{1} h_{\alpha, \beta_{0}}+t_{2} h_{\alpha_{0}, \beta}+t_{1} t_{2} h_{\alpha, \beta}\right)
$$

This last equality implies that for a generic choice of $t_{1}, t_{2}$ the strict transform of the polar curve $\Pi_{\alpha_{0}+t_{1} \alpha, \beta_{0}+t_{2} \beta}^{*}$ does not pass through the point $p$. It follows that $p$ is not a basepoint for the family $\Pi_{F}$.

Assume that $\Pi_{\alpha \beta}^{*}$ passes through $p$ for every $(\alpha, \beta)$ in $W_{I}^{\pi}$ or equivalently that $S_{\alpha \beta}(0,0)=$ $0, \forall(\alpha, \beta) \in W_{I}^{\pi}$. Denote by $I_{p}$ the ideal of $\mathbb{C}\{x, y\}$ generated by the finite set $\left\{h_{i j}(x, y):=\right.$ $\left.x^{m_{v}(i, j)-\nu_{v}(I)} \phi_{i j}(x, y)\right\}_{i \neq j}$. Since $S_{\alpha \beta}(0,0)=0, \forall(\alpha, \beta) \in W_{I}^{\pi}$ it follows that $h_{i j}(0,0)=0$ for all $i, j \in\{1, \ldots, k\}$ thus $I_{p}$ contains a power of the maximal ideal of $\mathbb{C}\{x, y\}$. Consider the blow-up $\mathrm{BL}_{I_{p}}$ of the ideal $I_{p}$. By Proposition 2.7 the modification $\mathrm{BL}_{I_{p}}$ has no basepoint for the family of curves $\left\{\sum_{i \neq j} \gamma_{i j} h_{i j}=0\right\}_{\left[\gamma_{i j}\right] \in \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k^{2}-k}\right)}$. Let $O_{p}$ be the Zariski open set of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k^{2}-k}\right)$ such that the strict transforms of the curves $\left\{\sum_{i \neq j} \gamma_{i j} h_{i j}=0\right\}_{\left[\gamma_{i j}\right] \in O_{p}}$ by $\mathrm{BL}_{I_{p}}$ do not intersect. Consider the continuous map $P: \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \longrightarrow \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k^{2}-k}\right), P(\alpha, \beta)=\left[\alpha_{i} \beta_{j}\right]_{i \neq j}$ and consider the Zariski open set $V_{p}=P^{-1}\left(O_{p}\right)$. It follows that the strict transforms of the curves $\left\{S_{\alpha \beta}=\sum_{i \neq j} \alpha_{i} \beta_{j} h_{i j}=0\right\}_{(\alpha, \beta) \in V_{p}}$ do not intersect which leads us to conclude that $\mathrm{BL}_{I_{p}}$ does not have basepoints for the family $\left\{\sum_{i \neq j} \alpha_{i} \beta_{j} h_{i j}=0\right\}_{(\alpha, \beta) \in \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)}$. We perform the same operation for every smooth basepoint of the family $\Pi_{F}$ in order to get the desired good resolution. A similar argument works if $p$ is a double point of $E$.

Now, let $G=\left(g_{1}, \ldots, g_{l}\right)$ be another precomplete system of generators for $I$. Let $\pi_{F}:\left(X_{F}, E_{F}\right) \longrightarrow$ $(X, 0)$ be any good resolution which has no basepoints for the family $\Pi_{F}$. We will prove that $\pi_{F}$ has no basepoints for the family $\Pi_{G}$. Since $G$ is precomplete then for every couple $(\alpha, \beta) \in$ $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ we have

$$
\pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} F_{\alpha} \wedge \mathrm{d} F_{\beta}\right)=\sum_{i \neq j} \psi_{i j}^{\alpha \beta} \pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} g_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} g_{j}\right)
$$

Let $p$ be a smooth point of an irreducible component $E_{v}$ of $E_{F}$. We are going to prove that $p$ is not a basepoint for the family $\Pi_{G}$. Let $(x, y)$ be a local coordinate system of $X_{F}$ centered at $p$ such that $x=0$ is the equation of $E_{F}$. It follows from Lemma 2.11 and our hypothesis that $\pi_{F}$ has no basepoints for the family $\Pi_{F}$, that is

$$
\pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} F_{\alpha} \wedge \mathrm{d} F_{\beta}\right)=x^{\nu_{v}(I)} S_{\alpha \beta}(x, y) \mathrm{d} x \wedge \mathrm{~d} y, \text { with } S_{\alpha \beta}(0,0) \neq 0
$$

for all $(\alpha, \beta)$ in a Zariski open set $O_{p}$ of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$. Then, using Equality (7), we obtain the existence of $i_{0}, j_{0} \in\{1, \ldots, l\}$ such that

$$
\pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} g_{i_{0}} \wedge \mathrm{~d} g_{j_{0}}\right)=x^{\nu_{v}(I)} S_{0}(x, y) \mathrm{d} x \wedge \mathrm{~d} y
$$

and $S_{0}(0,0) \neq 0$. With a similar argument as the one we previously used in the proof of the existence of $\pi_{F}$ we get that $p$ is not a basepoint for the family $\Pi_{G}$. The same argument works if $p$ is a double point of $E_{F}$.

Now, we are ready to state and prove the result we announced in Subsection 2.1.
Proposition 2.15. Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity and let $I$ be a m-primary ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. Let $F=\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ be a precomplete system of generators for $I$. Let $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution which factors through the blow-up of the ideal I and the principalization of the $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$-module $\Omega_{I}^{2}$. There exists a Zariski open set $V_{I}^{\pi}$ of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ such that for any irreducible component $E_{v}$ of $E$ and any element $(\alpha, \beta)$ of $V_{I}^{\pi}$ we have the equality

$$
q_{F_{\alpha}, v}^{F_{\beta}}=q_{v}^{I}
$$

where $q_{v}^{I}$ is the rational number of Definition 2.1.
Proof of Proposition 2.15. Let $V_{I}^{\pi}=\left(U_{I}^{\pi} \times U_{I}^{\pi}\right) \cap W_{I}^{\pi} \subset \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$, where $U_{I}^{\pi}, W_{I}^{\pi}$ are Zariski open sets as in Lemmas 2.8 and 2.11. Let $E_{v}$ be an irreducible component of $E$ and $p$ be a smooth point of $E$ in $E_{v}$. By Lemma 2.7 and Definition 2.14 there exists $(\alpha, \beta)$ in $V_{I}^{\pi}$ such that $p \notin F_{\alpha}^{*} \cup F_{\beta}^{*} \cup \Pi_{\alpha \beta}^{*}$. By Proposition 1.15 we have

$$
q_{F_{\alpha}, v}^{F_{\beta}}=\frac{\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} F_{\alpha} \wedge \mathrm{d} F_{\beta}\right)\right)-m_{v}\left(F_{\beta}\right)+1}{m_{v}\left(F_{\beta}\right)}
$$

Since $(\alpha, \beta)$ is an element of $V_{I}^{\pi}$ then by Lemmas 2.8 and 2.11 we have the equalities

$$
m_{v}\left(F_{\alpha}\right)=m_{v}\left(F_{\beta}\right)=m_{v}(I) \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} F_{\alpha} \wedge \mathrm{d} F_{\beta}\right)\right)=\nu_{v}(I)
$$

It implies that the number $q_{F_{\alpha}, v}^{F_{\beta}}$ does not depend on the choice of $(\alpha, \beta)$ in $V_{I}^{\pi}$ and

$$
q_{F_{\alpha}, v}^{F_{\beta}}=q_{v}^{I}:=\frac{\nu_{v}(I)-m_{v}(I)+1}{m_{v}(I)}
$$

To end this section, let us compare the inner rates associated with the maximal ideal $\mathfrak{m}$ of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$ with the inner rates of complex surface germ defined in [BdSFP22]. Let $(X, 0) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}, 0\right)$ be a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity at the origin of $\mathbb{C}^{n}$. Denote by $\mathbb{G}\left(2, \mathbb{C}^{n}\right)$ the grassmanian of complex planes of $\mathbb{C}^{n}$. Consider the Gauss map

$$
\begin{aligned}
\gamma: X \backslash\{0\} & \rightarrow \mathbb{G}\left(2, \mathbb{C}^{n}\right) \\
p & \mapsto T_{p} X
\end{aligned}
$$

which associates to each point $p$ of $X \backslash\{0\}$ the tangent plane of $X$ at $p$, and take the closure of its graph:

$$
\mathcal{N}(X):=\overline{\operatorname{Graph}(\gamma)}=\overline{\left\{(p, H) \in X \backslash 0 \times \mathbb{G}\left(2, \mathbb{C}^{n}\right) \mid T_{p} X=H\right\}} \subset \mathbb{C}^{n} \times \mathbb{G}\left(2, \mathbb{C}^{n}\right)
$$

Definition 2.16. The Nash transform of $X$ is the modification $\nu$ defined by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nu: \mathcal{N}(X) & \rightarrow X \\
(p, H) & \mapsto p
\end{aligned}
$$

Proposition 2.17 ([BdSFP22, Lemma 3.2]). Let $(X, 0) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}, 0\right)$ be a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity and $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution which factors through the Nash transform of $X$ and the blow-up of the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$.

There exists a rational number $q_{v} \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0}$ such that for any pair of curvettes $\gamma_{1}^{*}$ and $\gamma_{2}^{*}$ of an irreducible component $E_{v}$ of the exceptional divisor $E$ we have

$$
\mathrm{d}\left(\gamma_{1} \cap \mathbb{S}_{\epsilon}, \gamma_{2} \cap \mathbb{S}_{\epsilon}\right)=\Theta\left(e^{q_{v}}\right)
$$

where $\gamma_{1}=\pi\left(\gamma_{1}^{*}\right), \gamma_{2}=\pi\left(\gamma_{2}^{*}\right)$ and d is the arc length distance induced by $\mathbb{C}^{n}$ on $X$.
Furthermore, there exists a Zariski open set $\Omega_{\pi}$ of $\mathbb{G}\left(n-2, \mathbb{C}^{n}\right)$ such that for any linear projection $\ell=\left(\ell_{1}, \ell_{2}\right):(X, 0) \longrightarrow\left(\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0\right)$ whose kernel is an element of $\Omega_{\pi}$ we have $q_{v}=q_{v, \ell_{1}}^{\ell_{2}}$.
Definition 2.18 ([BdSFP22, Definition 3.3]). The rational number $q_{v}$ is the inner rate of $(X, 0)$ along $E_{v}$. We will say that a linear projection $\ell=\left(\ell_{1}, \ell_{2}\right)$ as in Proposition 2.17 is generic with respect to $\pi$. The polar curve of such a projection is also said to be generic with respect to $\pi$. In this case we also say the linear forms $\ell_{1}$ and $\ell_{2}$ are generic and the curves $\ell_{1}^{-1}(0)$ and $\ell_{2}^{-1}(0)$ are said to be generic hyperplane sections.

In the following remark we will explain that the inner rate associated to the maximal ideal coincides with the inner rate in the sense of Definition 2.18.
Remark 2.19. The inner rate $q_{v}$ of $(X, 0) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}, 0\right)$ along $E_{v}$ coincide with the number $q_{v}^{\mathfrak{m}}$, where $\mathfrak{m}$ is the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. Indeed, consider the linear forms

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{r}
P_{i}: \mathbb{C}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{C} \\
\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right) \mapsto z_{i}
\end{array}\right\} \cdot
$$

The family of linear forms $P=\left(P_{1}, \ldots, P_{n}\right)$ is a precomplete system of generators for $\mathfrak{m}$. By Proposition 2.15, there exists a Zariski open set $V_{\mathfrak{m}}^{\pi}$ of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}\right)$ such that for any elements $(\alpha, \beta) \in V_{\mathfrak{m}}^{\pi}$ we have $q_{v}^{\mathfrak{m}}=q_{v, P_{\alpha}}^{P_{\beta}}$. Denote by $H_{\alpha, \beta}$ the kernel of the linear projection $\ell_{\alpha, \beta}=\left(P_{\alpha}, P_{\beta}\right)$. The set $\overline{V_{\mathfrak{m}}^{\pi}}=\left\{H_{\alpha \beta} \mid \alpha, \beta \in V_{\mathfrak{m}}^{\pi}\right\}$ is a Zariski open set of $\mathbb{G}\left(n-2, \mathbb{C}^{n}\right)$. By Lemma 2.17 there exists a Zariski open set $\Omega_{\pi}$ of $\mathbb{G}\left(n-2, \mathbb{C}^{n}\right)$ such that $q_{v}=q_{v, \ell_{1}}^{\ell_{2}}$ whenever $\ell=\left(\ell_{1}, \ell_{2}\right)$ is a linear projection whose kernel is an element of $\Omega_{\pi}$. It follows that for any linear projection $\ell=\left(\ell_{1}, \ell_{2}\right)$ whose kernel is an element $\Omega_{\pi} \cap \overline{V_{\mathfrak{m}}^{\pi}}$ we have $q_{v}=q_{v, \ell_{1}}^{\ell_{2}}=q_{v}^{\mathfrak{m}}$.

# 3. InNER RATE FUNCTION OF AN M-PRIMARY IDEAL 

Let us define a metric on the quasi-monomial valuations of $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ compatible with $I$ following [BdSFP22, Subsection 2.3]. We start by doing it on any graph $\Gamma_{\pi}$ where $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ is a good resolution which factors through the blow up of $I$ and the principalization of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$. Let us endow the dual graph $\Gamma_{\pi}$ with a metric by declaring the length of an edge $e_{v, v^{\prime}}$ to be

$$
\operatorname{length}_{I}\left(e_{v, v^{\prime}}\right)=\frac{1}{m_{v}(I) m_{v^{\prime}}(I)}
$$

Now, let $p$ be an intersection point between two irreducible components $E_{v}$ and $E_{v^{\prime}}$ of $E$ and let $\tilde{\pi}:\left(X_{\tilde{\pi}}, \tilde{E}\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be the good resolution obtained by blowing up the point $p$. Then,

the exceptional component $E_{w}$ that arises has multiplicity $m_{w}(I)=m_{v}(I)+m_{v^{\prime}}(I)$. Since $\frac{1}{m_{w}(I) m_{v}(I)}+\frac{1}{m_{w}(I) m_{v^{\prime}}(I)}=\frac{1}{m_{v}(I) m_{v^{\prime}}(I)}$ (by Lemma 3.5), the inclusion of $\Gamma_{\pi}$ in $\Gamma_{\bar{\pi}}$ is an isometry. Therefore, by passing to the direct limit, the metric on the dual graphs $\Gamma_{\pi}$ defines a distance denoted $\mathrm{d}_{I}$ on the quasi-monomial valuations of $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$.
Remark 3.1. We cannot define a distance on $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$, since it is not a metrizable space (see right after Remark 2.3 of [GR21]). However, we can define a distance on the set of quasi-onomial valuations as outlined below. This distance, however, will not be compatible with the topology of the non-archimedean link in the sense that it will define a stronger topology. See [GR21, Theorem 2.29].
Definition 3.2. We call $d_{I}$ the skeletal metric on $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ with respect to $I$. When we want to specify the distance on the quasi-monomial valuations of $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ we will adopt the notation $\left(\mathrm{NL}(X, 0), \mathrm{d}_{I}\right)$.
Proposition 3.3. There exists a unique continuous function

$$
\mathcal{I}_{I}:\left(\mathrm{NL}(X, 0), \mathrm{d}_{I}\right) \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}_{>0} \cup\{+\infty\}
$$

such that $\mathcal{I}_{I}(v)=q_{v}^{I}$ for every divisorial point $v$ of $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$. If $\pi$ is a good resolution of $(X, 0)$ which factors through the blow-up of $I$ and the principalization of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$ then $\mathcal{I}_{I}$ is linear on the edges of $\Gamma_{\pi}$.
Definition 3.4. The function $\mathcal{I}_{I}$ is called the inner rates function with respect to the ideal $I$.

We get Proposition 3.3 by going through the exact same proof as [BdSFP22, Lemma 3.8], using the following Lemma 3.5 instead of [BdSFP22, Lemma 3.6].
Lemma 3.5. Let $I$ be an m-primary ideal for $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$ and $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution of $(X, 0)$ which factors through the blow-up of $I$ and the principalization of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$. Let $E_{v}$ be an irreducible component of $E$. Let $p$ be a point of $E_{v}$ and let $E_{w}$ be the exceptional component created by the blow-up of $X_{\pi}$ at $p$. Then:
(i) if $p$ is a smooth point of $E$, then

$$
m_{w}(I)=m_{v}(I) \quad \text { and } \quad q_{w}^{I}=q_{v}^{I}+\frac{1}{m_{v}(I)}
$$

(ii) if $p$ is a double point of $E_{v}$ and $E_{v^{\prime}}$, then

$$
m_{w}(I)=m_{v}(I)+m_{v^{\prime}}(I) \quad \text { and } \quad q_{w}^{I}=\frac{q_{v}^{I} m_{v}(I)+q_{v^{\prime}}^{I} m_{v^{\prime}}(I)}{m_{v}(I)+m_{v^{\prime}}(I)}
$$

Proof. Let $F=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ be a precomplete system of generators for $I$. Let $V_{I, p}^{\pi}$ be the subset of the open Zariski set $V_{I}^{\pi}$ of Proposition 2.15 such that for all elements $(\alpha, \beta)$ in $V_{I, p}^{\pi}$, we have

$$
p \notin\left(F_{\alpha}^{*} \cup F_{\beta}^{*} \cup \Pi_{\alpha \beta}^{*}\right)
$$

Since $\pi$ factors through the blow-up of $I$ and the principalization of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$ by Lemma 2.7 and Definition $2.14, V_{I, p}^{\pi}$ is also a Zariski open set of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$.

Proof of $(i)$ :
Assume that $p$ is a smooth point of an irreducible component $E_{v}$ of $E$. Let $(x, y)$ be a local system of coordinates centered at $p$ such that $x=0$ is the local equation of $E_{v}$. Let $(\alpha, \beta)$ be an element of $V_{I, p}^{\pi}$. In this case,

$$
F_{\alpha} \circ \pi(x, y)=x^{m_{v}(I)} U_{\alpha}(x, y), \quad F_{\beta} \circ \pi(x, y)=x^{m_{v}(I)} U_{\beta}(x, y)
$$

where $U_{\alpha}, U_{\beta}$ are units of $\mathcal{O}_{X_{\pi}, p}$. Let $\mathrm{BL}_{p}$ be the blow-up centered at $p$ and denote by $E_{w}$ the resulting irreducible component. In the coordinates chart $(x, y)=\left(x^{\prime}, x^{\prime} y^{\prime}\right)$, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
F_{\alpha} \circ \pi \circ \mathrm{BL}_{p}\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right)=x^{\prime m_{v}(I)} U_{\alpha}\left(x^{\prime}, x^{\prime} y^{\prime}\right) \\
F_{\beta} \circ \pi \circ \mathrm{BL}_{p}\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right)=x^{\prime m_{v}(I)} U_{\beta}\left(x^{\prime}, x^{\prime} y^{\prime}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

which means that $m_{w}(I)=m_{v}(I)$. Furthermore, since $F_{\alpha}^{*}, F_{\beta}^{*}$ and $\Pi_{\alpha, \beta}^{*}$ do not pass through the point $p$, it follows that they do not meet the component $E_{w}$. We then get the equality

$$
q_{w}^{I}=q_{v}^{I}+\frac{1}{m_{v}(I)}
$$

as a direct consequence of Theorem 1.17 applied to the component $E_{w}$.
Proof of (ii):
Assume that $p$ is an intersecting point of two irreducible components $E_{v}$ and $E_{v^{\prime}}$ of $E$. Let $(x, y)$ be a local system of coordinates centered at $p$ such that $x=0$ and $y=0$ are the local equations of $E_{v}$ and $E_{v^{\prime}}$, respectively. Let $(\alpha, \beta)$ be an element of $V_{I, p}^{*}$. In this case,

$$
F_{\alpha} \circ \pi(x, y)=x^{m_{v}(I)} y^{m_{v^{\prime}}(I)} U_{\alpha}(x, y), \quad F_{\beta} \circ \pi(x, y)=x^{m_{v}(I)} y^{m_{v^{\prime}}(I)} U_{\beta}(x, y)
$$

where $U_{\alpha}, U_{\beta}$ are units of $\mathcal{O}_{X_{\pi}, p}$. Let $\mathrm{BL}_{p}$ be the blow-up centered at $p$ and denote by $E_{w}$ the resulting irreducible component. In the coordinates chart $(x, y)=\left(x^{\prime}, x^{\prime} y^{\prime}\right)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& F_{\alpha} \circ \pi \circ \mathrm{BL}_{p}\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right)=x^{\prime m_{v}(I)}\left(x^{\prime} y^{\prime}\right)^{m_{v^{\prime}}(I)} U_{\alpha}\left(x^{\prime}, x^{\prime} y^{\prime}\right) \\
& F_{\beta} \circ \pi \circ \mathrm{BL}_{p}\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right)=x^{\prime m_{v}(I)}\left(x^{\prime} y^{\prime}\right)^{m_{v^{\prime}}(I)} U_{\beta}\left(x^{\prime}, x^{\prime} y^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which means that $m_{w}(I)=m_{v}(I)+m_{v^{\prime}}(I)$. Furthermore, since $F_{\alpha}^{*}, F_{\beta}^{*}$ and $\Pi_{\alpha, \beta}^{*}$ do not pass through the point $p$, it follows that they do not meet the component $E_{w}$. We then get the equality

$$
q_{w}^{I}=\frac{q_{v}^{I} m_{v}(I)+q_{v^{\prime}}^{I} m_{v^{\prime}}(I)}{m_{v}(I)+m_{v^{\prime}}(I)}
$$

as a direct consequence of Theorem 1.17 applied again to the component $E_{w}$.
Proof of Proposition 3.3. Let $I$ be an m primary ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$ and $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution of $(X, 0)$ which factors through the blow-up of $I$ and the principalization of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$.
