We only need to show that the inner rates with respect to $I$ extend uniquely to a continuous map on $\Gamma_{\pi}$ which is linear on its edges with integral slopes, because $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ is homeomorphic to the inverse limit of dual graphs.
Let $e_{v v^{\prime}}$ be an edge of $\Gamma_{\pi}$. The slope of $\mathcal{I}_{I}$ on $e_{v, v^{\prime}}$ is $\frac{q_{v^{\prime}}^{\prime}-q_{v}^{I}}{\operatorname{length}_{I}\left(e_{v v^{\prime}}\right)}=m_{v}(I) m_{v^{\prime}}(I)\left(q_{v^{\prime}}^{I}-q_{v}^{I}\right)$ and it is an integer by Definition 2.1.

By density of the divisorial valuations (Remark 1.12), it is sufficient to prove the linearity of $\mathcal{I}_{I}$ along $e_{v v^{\prime}}$ on the set of the divisorial valuations. On the other hand, since every divisorial point of that edge are obtained by successively blowing up its double points, it is sufficient to prove that $\mathcal{I}_{I}$ is linear on the set $\left\{v, v^{\prime}, v^{\prime \prime}\right\}$, where $v^{\prime \prime}$ is obtained by blowing up the double point $E_{v} \cap E_{v^{\prime}}$. Therefore, all we have to show is that

$$
\frac{\mathcal{I}_{I}\left(v^{\prime}\right)-\mathcal{I}_{I}(v)}{\operatorname{length}_{I}\left(e_{v v^{\prime}}\right)}=\frac{\mathcal{I}_{I}\left(v^{\prime \prime}\right)-\mathcal{I}_{I}(v)}{\operatorname{length}_{I}\left(e_{v v^{\prime \prime}}\right)}
$$

Since the good resolution $\pi$ factors through the blow-up of $I$ and the principalization of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$ the equality (8) is a direct consequence of point (ii) of Lemma 3.5.

Now, let us state the principal result of this section, which tells us that the inner rate function associated to an m-primary ideal is completely determined by its values on the vertices of the dual graph of the minimal good resolution of $(X, 0)$ which factors through the blow-up of $I$ and the principalization of the $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$-module $\Omega_{I}^{2}$.

Proposition 3.6. Let $I$ and $J$ be two m-primary ideals of the local ring $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. Let $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow$ $(X, 0)$ be the minimal good resolution which factors through the blow-up of $I$ and the principalization of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$.

Then, $\mathcal{I}_{I}=\mathcal{I}_{J}$ if and only if the following conditions are verified

- The good resolution $\pi$ is the minimal good resolution which factors through the blow-up of $J$ and the principalization of $\Omega_{J}^{2}$.
- $m_{v}(I)=m_{v}(J)$ and $q_{v}^{I}=q_{v}^{J}$ for all vertices $v$ of $V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)$.

The following preliminary lemma is required to prove Proposition 3.6 and will have another interest in the last section of the paper.

Lemma 3.7. Let $I$ and $J$ be two m-primary ideals of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. Let $\overline{\mathrm{BL}_{I}}: \overline{\left(X_{I}, E_{I}\right)} \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ and $\overline{\mathrm{BL}_{J}}: \overline{\left(X_{J}, E_{J}\right)} \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be the normalized blow-ups of $I$ and $J$ respectively. If $\mathcal{I}_{I}=\mathcal{I}_{J}$ then I. $\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}=$ J. $\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}$, I. $\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{J}}}=$ J. $\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{J}}}$ and the modifications $\overline{\mathrm{BL}_{I}}$ and $\overline{\mathrm{BL}_{J}}$ are isomorphic i.e, each one factors through the other.

Proof. Let $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution which factors through the blow-ups of the ideals $I$ and $J$ and the principalizations of the $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$-modules $\Omega_{I}^{2}$ and $\Omega_{J}^{2}$. We first prove that the ideal sheaves $I . \mathcal{O}_{X_{\pi}}=\mathcal{O}_{X_{\pi}}\left(-\sum_{V} \operatorname{Ord}_{V}(I) V\right)$ and $J . \mathcal{O}_{X_{\pi}}=\mathcal{O}\left(-\sum_{V} \operatorname{Ord}_{V}(J) V\right)$ are equal, where $\operatorname{Ord}_{V}(I):=\min \left\{\operatorname{Ord}_{V}(h) \mid h \in I\right\}$ whenever $V$ is a curve embedded in $X_{\pi}$. Since $\pi$ factors through the blow-ups of $I$ and $J$ then, by Proposition 2.4, the ideal sheaves $I . \mathcal{O}_{X_{\pi}}$ and $J . \mathcal{O}_{X_{\pi}}$ are locally principal.

It remains to prove that their associated divisors are equal. Let $E_{v}$ be an irreducible component of $E$ and let us prove that $m_{v}(I)=m_{v}(J)$. Consider the blow-up centered at a smooth point of the component $E_{v}$ and denote by $E_{w}$ the resulting component. By hypothesis we have $q_{w}^{I}=q_{w}^{J}$ and it follow by Lemma 3.5 that

$$
q_{w}^{I}=q_{v}^{I}+\frac{1}{m_{v}(I)}=q_{v}^{J}+\frac{1}{m_{v}(J)}=q_{w}^{J}
$$

The equality below implies that $m_{v}(I)=m_{v}(J)$ because by hypothesis $q_{v}^{I}=q_{v}^{J}$. It follows that

$$
\text { I. } \mathcal{O}_{X_{\pi}}=J . \mathcal{O}_{X_{\pi}}
$$

Denote by $\overline{\mathrm{BL}_{I}}: \overline{\left(X_{I}, E_{I}\right)} \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ the normalized blow-up of $I$. We will prove that $I . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}=$ $J . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}$. Let $r:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow\left(\overline{X_{I}}, \bar{E}_{I}\right)$ be the modification such that $\overline{\mathrm{BL}}_{I} \circ r=\pi$. Let $p$ be a point of $\bar{E}_{I}$. Then, there exists $h \in\left(\mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}\right)_{p}$ such that $\left(I . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}\right)_{p}$ is generated by $h$. Then $h$ generates $\left(I . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}\right)_{q}$ for all $q$ in a neighborhood of $p$. Since $r$ is an isomorphism when restricting the image to a punctured neighborhood $U_{p}$ of $p$ in $\overline{X_{I}}, h$ must divide all functions of $\left(J . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}\right)_{p}$, that is, for all $\phi \in\left(J . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}\right)_{p}$, we have that $\phi=h . g$, for some function $g$. We claim that there exists a function $\phi$ such that $g$ is a unit. In fact, if this was not true, then after applying the modification $r$ we would have that $I . \mathcal{O}_{X_{\pi}}$ and $J . \mathcal{O}_{X_{\pi}}$ are distinct and it is a contradiction. We have proved that $I . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}=J . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}$ and by symmetry of the roles of $I$ and $J$ we have $I . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{J}}}=J . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{J}}}$.

By Proposition 2.4 the sheaf $I . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}$ is locally principal which means that it is also the case for $J . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}$. It implies that $\overline{\mathrm{BL}_{I}}$ factors through $\overline{\mathrm{BL}_{J}}$. We can also prove symmetrically that $\overline{\mathrm{BL}_{J}}$ factors through $\overline{\mathrm{BL}_{I}}$.

Now, we are ready to prove the main result of this section.
Proof of Proposition 3.6. - Assume that $\mathcal{I}_{I}=\mathcal{I}_{J}$ and let us prove first that $\pi$ factors through the blow-up of $J$ and the principalization of $\Omega_{J}^{2}$. By Lemma 3.7 the modifications $\overline{\mathrm{BL}}_{I}$ and $\overline{\mathrm{BL}}_{J}$ are isomorphic i.e, factors through each other. It follows that $\pi$ factors through $\mathrm{BL}_{J}$.

It remains to prove that $\pi$ factors through the principalization of $\Omega_{J}^{2}$. Let us suppose that there exists $F=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ a precomplete system of generators for $J$ such that $\pi$ has a basepoint for the family of polar curves $\Pi_{F}$. Let $p$ be a basepoint of $\pi$ for the family $\Pi_{F}$.

Assume first that $p$ is a smooth point of $E$. Denote by $E_{w}$ the irreducible component that arises from the blow-up of center $p$. By Lemma 3.5 we get that

$$
q_{w}^{I}=q_{v}^{I}+\frac{1}{m_{v}(I)}
$$

and by Theorem 1.17 applied to $E_{w}$ we get

$$
q_{w}^{J}=q_{v}^{J}+\frac{1+\Pi_{\alpha \beta}^{*} \cdot E_{w}}{m_{v}(J)}
$$

On the other hand, we have $I . \mathcal{O}_{X_{\pi}}=J . \mathcal{O}_{X_{\pi}}$, indeed, by Lemma 3.7 the ideal sheaves $I . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}$ and $J . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}$ are equal. It follows that their pull back in $X_{\pi}$ are also equal. In particular, $m_{v}(I)=m_{v}(J)$ and we have by hypothesis $q_{v}^{I}=q_{v}^{J}$ and $q_{w}^{I}=q_{w}^{J}$. This contradicts the equalities (9) and (10) and it proves that $p$ cannot be a basepoint for the family $\Pi_{F}$.

Assume now that $p$ is a double point of $E$. Let $E_{v_{1}}$ and $E_{v_{2}}$ be the irreducible components of $E$ which intersects at $p$. Let $E_{w}$ be the irreducible component that arrises from the blow-up of the point $p$. Lemma 3.5 implies that

$$
q_{w}^{I}=\frac{q_{v_{1}}^{I}+q_{v_{2}}^{I}}{m_{v_{1}}(I)+m_{v_{2}}(I)}
$$

On the other hand the inner rate formula 1.17 gives

$$
q_{w}^{J}=\frac{\Pi_{\alpha \beta}^{*} \cdot E_{w}+q_{v_{1}}^{J}+q_{v_{2}}^{J}}{m_{v_{1}}(J)+m_{v_{2}}(J)}
$$

Again, the equalities (11) and (12) contradicts the hypothesis $\mathcal{I}_{I}=\mathcal{I}_{J}$. We proved that $\pi$ factors through the principalization of $\Omega_{J}^{2}$.

We have the equalities $m_{v}(I)=m_{v}(J)$ and $q_{v}^{I}=q_{v}^{J}$ for all $v \in V\left(\Gamma_{\pi}\right)$ because $\mathcal{I}_{I}=\mathcal{I}_{J}$.

- Conversely, if $\pi$ factors through the blow-ups of $I$ and $J$ and the principalizations of $\Omega_{2}^{I}$ and $\Omega_{2}^{J}$ and if $q_{v}^{I}=q_{v}^{J}, m_{v}(I)=m_{v}(J)$ for all vertices $v$ of $\Gamma_{\pi}$ then it follows directly from Lemma 3.5 that $\mathcal{I}_{I}=\mathcal{I}_{J}$.

# 4. GEOMETRIC INTERPRETATION OF THE INNER RATES ASSOCIATED TO AN IDEAL 

Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity and $I$ be an m-primary ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. The aim of this section is to give a geometric interpretation of the inner rates associated to $I$ as the inner rates of a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity embedded in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$ (Theorem 4.1).

Now, we are ready to state the main result of this section which enables us to introduce in Definition 4.3 the notion of complete generator system for $I$. Recall that the skeletal metric $d_{I}$ was defined in Definition 3.2.

Theorem 4.1 (Theorem C). Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity and I be a $\mathfrak{m}$-primary ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. There exists a precomplete system of generators $F=\left(f_{1}, f_{2}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ of $I$ such that the holomorphic map

$$
\begin{aligned}
F:(X, 0) & \rightarrow(F(X), 0) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}, 0\right) \\
p & \mapsto\left(f_{1}(p), f_{2}(p), \ldots, f_{k}(p)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

verifies the following properties:
(i) The image $(F(X), 0)$ is a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity at the origin of $\mathbb{C}^{k}$.
(ii) The map $F$ is a homeomorphism on its image and a modification of $(F(X), 0)$.
(iii) The induced map $\tilde{F}:\left(\mathrm{NL}(X, 0), \mathrm{d}_{I}\right) \longrightarrow\left(\mathrm{NL}(F(X), 0), \mathrm{d}_{\mathfrak{m}_{F}}\right)$ is an isometry which makes the following diagram commute
![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)
where $\mathfrak{m}_{F}$ is the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{F(X), 0}$.
Remark 4.2. If we assume in the statement of Theorem 4.1 that the germ $(X, 0)$ is normal then the morphism $F$ is the normalization of the complex surface germ $(F(X), 0)$ because it is, in particular, a finite modification.
Definition 4.3. We will say that a system of generators for $I$ is complete if it verifies the properties (i), (ii) and (iii) of Theorem 4.1.

This notion is a strengthening of the notion of precompleteness introduced in Definition 2.9.
Given a complex surface germ $(X, 0)$ with an isolated singularity, Theorem 4.1 enables us to construct complex surface germs homeomorphic to $(X, 0)$ whose metric invariants (inner rates of complex surface germs) are prescribed by an ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. Besides providing a nice geometric interpretation for the inner rates associated with an ideal, we will later see that it is a powerful tool for explicitly constructing many complex surface germs that are homeomorphic to a given one but have distinct metric types.

In order to prove Theorem 4.1 we also need the following theorem of Remmert which gives us a sufficient condition for the image of a complex space by a holomorphic map to be a complex space.
Theorem 4.4 ([Dem12, Remmert's proper mapping theorem]). Let $f: X \longrightarrow Y$ be a proper holomorphic map. Then $f(X)$ is an analytic set embedded in $Y$.

Example 4.5. For example, one can define the Whitney umbrella as the image of $\mathbb{C}^{2}$ by the map $(x, y) \in \mathbb{C}^{2} \mapsto\left(x y, x, y^{2}\right)$ and whose equation is $z_{1}^{2}=z_{2}^{2} z_{3}$. But if we choose a non proper holomorphic map $(x, y) \in \mathbb{C}^{2} \mapsto\left(x y, y^{2}\right)$ then the image $\mathbb{C}^{2}-\{(x, 0) \mid x \neq 0\}$ is dense thus not an analytic set embedded in $\mathbb{C}^{2}$.

Proof of Theorem 4.1. Let $\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ be a precomplete system of generators for $I$.

- We will first prove that the morphism

$$
\begin{aligned}
G:(X, 0) & \rightarrow\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}, 0\right) \\
p & \mapsto\left(f_{1}(p), f_{2}(p) \ldots, f_{k}(p)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

is an immersion on $X \backslash 0$.
Assume that $G$ is not an immersion. It follows that there exists a point $p$ of $X \backslash 0$ such that $\mathrm{d} f_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} f_{j}(p)=0$ for all $i, j=1, \ldots, k$.

Let $\left(\ell_{1}, \ldots, \ell_{r}\right)$ be a system of generators for the maximal ideal $\mathfrak{m}$ of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. Therefore the following morphism is an embedding

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ell:(X, 0) & \rightarrow\left(\mathbb{C}^{r}, 0\right) \\
p & \mapsto\left(\ell_{1}(p), \ell_{2}(p), \ldots, \ell_{r}(p)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\ell$ is in particular a biholomorphism on its image there exists $i, j, m \in\{1, \ldots, r\}$ such that $\ell_{m}(p) \neq 0$ and $\mathrm{d} \ell_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} \ell_{j}(p) \neq 0$.

By hypothesis, there exists a natural number $n$ such that $\mathfrak{m}^{n} \subset I$. Consider the functions $F_{i m}^{(a b)}=\left(a \ell_{i}+b \ell_{m}\right)^{n}$ and $F_{j m}^{(c d)}=\left(c \ell_{j}+d \ell_{m}\right)^{n}$, where $a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{C}$. Since $F_{i m}^{(a b)}$ and $F_{j m}^{(c d)}$ are elements of $I$ then $\omega=\mathrm{d} F_{i m}^{(a b)} \wedge \mathrm{d} F_{j m}^{(c d)}$ is an element of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$

$$
\omega=n^{2}\left(a \ell_{i}+b \ell_{m}\right)^{n-1}\left(c \ell_{j}+d \ell_{m}\right)^{n-1}\left(a c\left(\mathrm{~d} \ell_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} \ell_{j}\right)+a d\left(\mathrm{~d} \ell_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} \ell_{m}\right)+b c\left(\mathrm{~d} \ell_{m} \wedge \mathrm{~d} \ell_{j}\right)\right)
$$

Let us choose $a, b, c$ and $d$ such that $\omega(p) \neq 0$. By assumption, $\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{k}\right)$ is a precomplete system of generators for $I$ hence there exists a family of functions $\left\{\psi_{i j}\right\}_{1 \leq i, j \leq k}$ such that

$$
\omega=\sum_{1 \leq i, j \leq k} \psi_{i j} \mathrm{~d} f_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} f_{j}
$$

This last equality cannot happen if $\mathrm{d} f_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} f_{j}(p)=0$ for all $1 \leq i, j \leq k$. This contradiction shows that the map $G$ is an immersion on $X \backslash 0$.

But the map $G$ is not necessarily injective, let us then consider the following holomorphic map

$$
\begin{aligned}
F:(X, 0) \rightarrow & \left(\mathbb{C}^{k+k r}, 0\right) \\
p \mapsto & \left(f_{1}(p), f_{2}(p) \ldots, f_{k}(p), f_{1}(p) \ell_{1}(p), f_{1}(p) \ell_{2}(p)\right. \\
& \left.\ldots, f_{1}(p) \ell_{r}(p), \ldots, f_{k}(p) \ell_{1}(p), \ldots, f_{k}(p) \ell_{r}(p)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We can directly check that $F$ is injective by using the fact that $\left(\ell_{1}\left(p_{1}\right), \ldots, \ell_{r}\left(p_{1}\right)\right) \neq\left(\ell_{1}\left(p_{2}\right), \ldots, \ell_{r}\left(p_{2}\right)\right)$ for all $p_{1} \neq p_{2}$ in $X$.

- Let us prove that $F$ is proper. For that, first we prove that $F$ is a local biholomorphism from $X \backslash 0$ to $F(X) \backslash 0$. Let $p_{0}$ be a non singular point of $X$. There exists $i_{0} \in\{1, \ldots, k\}$ such that $f_{i_{0}}\left(p_{0}\right) \neq 0$ because the ideal $I$ is $\mathfrak{m}$-primary. Denote by $U_{0}$ an open neighborhood of $p_{0}$ such that $f_{i_{0}}$ does not vanish on $U_{0}$. Let us consider the holomorphic map

$$
\begin{gathered}
h: \mathbb{C}^{k+r k} \backslash\left\{z_{i_{0}} \neq 0\right\} \longrightarrow \mathbb{C}^{r} \\
h\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{k}, z_{1,1}, z_{1,2}, \ldots, z_{1, r}, \ldots, z_{k, 1}, \ldots, z_{k, r}\right)=\left(\frac{z_{i_{0}, 1}}{z_{i_{0}}}, \ldots, \frac{z_{i_{0}, r}}{z_{i_{0}}}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

The composed map $h \circ F_{\mid U_{0}}(p)=\left(\ell_{1}(p), \ldots, \ell_{r}(p)\right)=\ell_{\mid U_{0}}$ is a biholomorphism from $U_{0}$ to $\ell\left(U_{0}\right)$ by definition of $\ell$. We have the equality $F_{\mid F\left(U_{0}\right)}^{-1}=\left(\ell^{-1} \circ h\right)_{\mid F\left(U_{0}\right)}$ which implies that $F_{\mid U_{0}}$ is a biholomorphism on its image. It follows that $F_{\mid X \backslash 0}: X \backslash 0 \longrightarrow F(X) \backslash 0$ is a biholomorphism. The map $F$ is continuous at 0 because it is holomorphic. It implies that $F$ is a proper homeomorphism and by Theorem 4.4 we get that $(F(X), 0)$ is a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity. We proved that the system of generators $F_{I}=\left(f_{1}, f_{2} \ldots, f_{k}, f_{1} \ell_{1}, f_{1} \ell_{2}, \ldots, f_{1} \ell_{r}, \ldots, f_{k} \ell_{1}, \ldots, f_{k} \ell_{r}\right)$ of the ideal $I$ is complete.

- Now, let us study the induced map $\tilde{F}: \mathrm{NL}(X, 0) \longrightarrow \mathrm{NL}(F(X), 0)$ defined on the nonarchimedean link of $(X, 0)$. Since $F$ is also a modification, the comorphism $F^{*}: \operatorname{Frac}\left(\mathcal{O}_{F(X), F(p)}\right) \longrightarrow$ $\operatorname{Frac}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X, p}\right)$ is an isomorphism. Therefore, the map $\tilde{F}$ is, by Proposition 1.13, a one-to-one continuous map.

Let us prove that $\mathcal{I}_{\mathfrak{m}_{F}} \circ \tilde{F}=\mathcal{I}_{I}$. Let val be a divisorial valuation of $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$. Let $\pi$ : $\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be a good resolution such that there exists an irreducible component $E_{v}$ of $E$ whose associated divisorial valuation is val. The image of val by $\tilde{F}$ is the valuation

$$
\tilde{F}(\text { val })(h)=\frac{m_{v}(h \circ F \circ \pi)}{m_{v}(\mathfrak{m})} \frac{1}{\operatorname{val}\left(F^{*} \mathfrak{m}_{F}\right)}=\frac{m_{v}(h \circ F \circ \pi)}{m_{v}(I)}, h \in \mathcal{O}_{F(X), 0}
$$

because

$$
\operatorname{val}\left(F^{*} \mathfrak{m}_{F}\right)=\operatorname{val}(I)=\frac{m_{v}(I)}{m_{v}(\mathfrak{m})}
$$

On the other hand, since $F$ is a modification, the map $\pi_{F}=F \circ \pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(F(X), 0)$ is a good resolution of $(F(X), 0)$. Denote by $v a l_{F}$ the divisorial valuation of $\mathrm{NL}(F(X), 0)$ associated to the irreducible component $E_{v}$ of $E$. Let $h$ be an element of $\mathcal{O}_{F(X), 0}$, we have

$$
\operatorname{val}_{F}(h)=\frac{m_{v}(h \circ F \circ \pi)}{m_{v}\left(m_{F}\right)}=\tilde{F}(\text { val })(h)
$$

because

$$
m_{v}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{F}\right)=\inf \left\{\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}(h \circ F \circ \pi) \mid h \in \mathfrak{m}_{F}\right\}=m_{v}(I)
$$

Furthermore, we have

$$
\nu_{v}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{F}\right)=\inf \left\{\operatorname{Ord}_{E_{v}}\left(\pi_{F}^{*}(\mathrm{~d} g \wedge \mathrm{~d} f)\right) \mid g, f \in \mathfrak{m}_{F}\right\}=\nu_{v}(I)
$$

because $F^{*} \mathfrak{m}_{F}=I$. It follows from (13), (14) and (15) that

$$
\mathcal{I}_{\mathfrak{m}_{F}} \circ \tilde{F}(\text { val })=\mathcal{I}_{\mathfrak{m}_{F}}\left(\operatorname{val}_{F}\right)=q_{v}^{\mathfrak{m}_{F}}=\frac{\nu_{v}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{F}\right)-m_{v}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{F}\right)+1}{m_{v}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{F}\right)}=\mathcal{I}_{I}(\text { val })
$$

because $\nu_{v}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{F}\right)=\nu_{v}(I)$ and $m_{v}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{F}\right)=m_{v}(I)$.
It remains to prove that $\tilde{F}:\left(\mathrm{NL}(X, 0), \mathrm{d}_{I}\right) \longrightarrow\left(\mathrm{NL}(F(X), 0), \mathrm{d}_{\mathfrak{m}_{F}}\right)$ is an isometry. Let $v$ and $v^{\prime}$ be two adjacent vertices of $\Gamma_{\pi}$. From what we done before, the image of the edge $e_{v, v^{\prime}}$ by $\tilde{F}$ is again the edge $e_{v, v^{\prime}}$ and we have:

$$
\mathrm{d}_{I}\left(v, v^{\prime}\right)=\frac{1}{m_{v}(I) m_{v^{\prime}}(I)}=\frac{1}{m_{v}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{F}\right) m_{v^{\prime}}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{F}\right)}=\mathrm{d}_{\mathfrak{m}_{F}}\left(v, v^{\prime}\right)
$$

It follows that $\tilde{F}$ is an isometry on the divisorial valuations and it follows by their density in $\mathrm{NL}(X, 0)$ that it is an isometry.

We end this section with an example which shows that a precomplete system of generators for an ideal is not necessarily complete.

Example 4.6. We have seen in Example 2.10 that the set $G=\left(x^{2}, y^{2}, x y^{2}, x^{2} y\right)$ is a precomplete system of generators of the ideal $I:=\left(x^{2}, y^{2}\right)$ of $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0}$. But $G$ is not complete. Indeed, the morphism $(x, y) \in \mathbb{C}^{2} \mapsto\left(x^{2}, y^{2}, x y^{2}, x^{2} y\right)$ is not injective because the points $(1,0)$ and $(-1,0)$ are both sent to the point $(1,0,0,0)$.

The set of generators $F=\left(x^{2}, y^{2}, x y^{2}, x^{2} y, x^{3}, y^{3}\right)$ is a complete set of generators for $I$ and the image of the morphism $(x, y) \in \mathbb{C}^{2} \mapsto\left(x^{2}, y^{2}, x y^{2}, x^{2} y, x^{3}, y^{3}\right) \in \mathbb{C}^{6}$ is a complex surface germ $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ embedded in $\mathbb{C}^{6}$ with an isolated singularity at the origin.

# 5. APPLICATION TO POLAR EXPLORATION AND OUTER LIPSCHITZ GEOMETRY 

Now we will apply Theorem 4.1 to polar exploration of complex surface germs in the sense of the paper by Belotto, Fantini, Némethi, and Pichon in [BdSFNP22].

Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ embedded in $\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}, 0\right)$ and consider $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ a good resolution of $(X, 0)$, and denote by $E_{v_{1}}, \ldots, E_{v_{n}}$ the irreducible components of $E$. Let $\ell=\left(\ell_{1}, \ell_{2}\right):(X, 0) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}, 0\right) \longrightarrow\left(\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0\right)$ be a generic projection with respect to $\pi$ in the sense of Definition 2.18. Denote by $\Pi$ the generic polar curve of $\ell$. As in [BdSFNP22], we associate to $\pi$ a triplet $\left(\Gamma_{\pi}, L_{\pi}, P_{\pi}\right)$, where $\Gamma_{\pi}$ is the dual graph of $\pi$, and vectors $L_{\pi}:=\left(\ell_{1}^{*} \cdot E_{v_{i}}\right)_{1 \leq i \leq n}$ and $P_{\pi}:=\left(\Pi^{*} \cdot E_{v_{i}}\right)_{1 \leq i \leq n}$ with $\ell_{1}^{*}$ and $\Pi^{*}$ being, respectively, the strict transforms of $\ell_{1}^{-1}(0)$ and the polar curve $\Pi$ by $\pi$. Belotto, Fantini, Némethi, and Pichon proved in [BdSFNP22] the following theorem.

Theorem 5.1 ([BdSFNP22, Theorem A]). Let $M$ be a real 3-manifold. There exists finitely many triples $(\Gamma, L, P)$, where $\Gamma$ is a weighted graph and $L$ and $P$ are vectors in $\left(\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}\right)^{V(\Gamma)}$, such that there exists a normal complex surface germ $(X, 0)$ satisfying the following conditions:
(i) The link of $(X, 0)$ is homeomorphic to $M$.
(ii) $(\Gamma, L, P)=\left(\Gamma_{\pi}, L_{\pi}, P_{\pi}\right)$, where $\pi:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ is the minimal good resolution which factors through the blow-up of the maximal ideal and the Nash transform of $(X, 0)$.
A natural question to ask is if the statement of Theorem [BdSFNP22, Theorem A] still holds if we do not restrict ourselves to normal surface singularities? Here, we give a negative answer to this question with the following result stated as Theorem A in the introduction.

We will need the notion of integral closure of ideals to state our result.
Definition 5.2. Let $I$ be an ideal of a commutative ring $R$. The integral closure of $I$ is the ideal, denoted $\bar{I}$, of all elements $r$ in $R$ such that there exists $a_{i} \in I^{i}$ satisfying the equality

$$
r^{n}+a_{1} r^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n-1} r+a_{1}=0
$$

Theorem 5.3 (Theorem A). Let $(X, 0)$ be a normal complex surface germ. Let $\Lambda_{X}$ be the infinite set of integrally closed $\mathfrak{m}$-primary ideals of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. There exists a family of complex surface germs with an isolated singularity $\left\{\left(X_{I}, 0\right)\right\}_{I \in \Lambda_{X}}$ such that
(i) $(X, 0)$ is homeomorphic to $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ for all $I \in \Lambda_{X}$ and is the common normalization of the germs $\left\{\left(X_{I}, 0\right)\right\}_{I \in \Lambda_{X}}$.
(ii) For all $I, J$ in $\Lambda_{X}$ we have that $\left(\Gamma_{\pi_{I}}, L_{\pi_{I}}, P_{\pi_{I}}\right)=\left(\Gamma_{\pi_{J}}, L_{\pi_{J}}, P_{\pi_{J}}\right)$ if and only if $I=J$, where $\pi_{I}$ and $\pi_{J}$ are respectively the minimal good resolutions which factors through the blow-ups of the maximal ideal and the Nash transform of $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ and $\left(X_{J}, 0\right)$.
In order to prove Theorem 5.3 we will need a preliminary result which gives a relationship between the inner rates and the integral closure of ideals (see [LJT08] for more knowledge on the integral closure of ideals).
Proposition 5.4. Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ and $I, J$ be two $\mathfrak{m}$-primary ideals of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. If the inner rates functions $\mathcal{I}_{I}$ and $\mathcal{I}_{J}$ are equal then $\bar{I}=\bar{J}$.

To prove Proposition 5.4 we need the following Theorem
Theorem 5.5 (See [Lë09, Theorem 1.1] or [LJT08, Theorem 2.1]). Let $(X, 0)$ be a germ of complex space. Let $I$ be an ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$ and $h$ be an element of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. The following conditions are equivalent:
(i) $h \in \bar{I}$
(ii) The function $h \circ \pi$ is a section of $I \cdot \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I}}}$, where $\overline{\mathrm{BL}_{I}}:\left(\overline{X_{I}}, \overline{E_{I}}\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ is the normalized blow-up of $I$.

Proof of Proposition 5.4. By Proposition 3.7 there exists, up to isomorphism, a modification

$$
\pi_{I J}:\left(\overline{X_{I J}}, \overline{E_{I J}}\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)
$$

which is the common normalized blow-up of the ideals $I$ and $J$. Let us prove that $\bar{I}=\bar{J}$, let $h$ be an element of $\bar{I}$. By Theorem 5.5 the function $h \circ \pi_{I J}$ is a section of $I \cdot \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I J}}}$. By Proposition 3.7 we have $I . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I J}}}=J . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I J}}}$ and it implies that $h \circ \pi_{I J}$ is a section of $J . \mathcal{O}_{\overline{X_{I J}}}$. Again, by Theorem 5.5 we get that $h$ is an element of $\bar{J}$. We proved that $\bar{I} \subset \bar{J}$. Symmetrically, we prove that $\bar{J} \subset \bar{I}$.
Remark 5.6. The converse of Proposition 5.4 is false. Indeed, consider again the ideal $I$ of $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0}$ generated by $\left(x^{2}, y^{2}\right)$. The integral closure $\bar{I}$ of the ideal $I$ is generated by $\left(x^{2}, y^{2}, x y\right)$ (see [Tei04, Proposition 3.4]). Let $\omega_{1}=\mathrm{d}\left(x^{2}\right) \wedge \mathrm{d}\left(y^{2}\right)$ and $\omega_{2}=\mathrm{d}\left(x^{2}\right) \wedge \mathrm{d}(x y)$. Consider the modification

$$
b:\left(X_{2}, E_{\nu_{1}} \cup E_{\nu_{2}}\right) \xrightarrow{b_{2}}\left(X_{1}, E_{\nu_{1}}\right) \xrightarrow{b_{1}}\left(\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0\right)
$$

where $b_{1}$ is the blow-up of the origin of $\mathbb{C}^{2}$ and $b_{2}$ is the blow-up centered at the point $x^{*} \cap E_{\nu_{1}}$. A direct computation using the holomorphic forms $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{2}$ shows that $\nu_{\nu_{2}}(I)=5, m_{\nu_{2}}(I)=2$ and $\nu_{\nu_{2}}(\bar{I})=4, m_{\nu_{2}}(\bar{I})=2$. It follows that

$$
q_{\nu_{2}}^{I}=2 \neq \frac{3}{2}=q_{\nu_{2}}^{\bar{I}}
$$

In order to prove this Theorem 5.3, we will also need the following result by Spivalovsky, which characterizes the Nash transform.
Theorem 5.7 ([Spi90, Theorem 1.2]). A modification of $(X, 0)$ factors through the Nash transform of $(X, 0)$ if and only if it has no basepoints for the family of the polar curves associated to the linear projections on $\mathbb{C}^{2}$.

Before going through the proof, let us give a concrete example of the construction we will use to prove Theorem 5.3 .

Example 5.8. Let $(X, 0)=\left(\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0\right)$ and consider the family of integrally closed m-primary ideal $\left\{I_{n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}^{*}}$ of $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0}$ generated by $G_{n}=\left(x^{k} y^{n-k}, 0 \leq k \leq n\right)$. The set of generators $G_{n}$ is not complete. Indeed, the points $(1,0)$ and $(\sqrt[n]{1}, 0)$, where $\sqrt[n]{1}$ is a root of unity not equal to 1 , are sent to the point $(0,0, \ldots, 1)$ by the morphism $(x, y) \mapsto\left(y^{n}, x y^{n-1}, x^{2} y^{n-2}, \ldots, x^{n-1} y, x^{n}\right)$.

Let us consider the complete set of generators

$$
\widetilde{G}_{n}=\left(y^{n+1}, y^{n}, x y^{n-1}, x^{2} y^{n-2}, \ldots, x^{n-1} y, x^{n}, x^{n+1}\right)
$$

for the ideal $I_{n}$. By Theorem 4.1 the image of the germ $\left(\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0\right)$ by the holomorphic map

$$
F_{n}(x, y)=\left(y^{n+1}, y^{n}, x y^{n-1}, x^{2} y^{n-2}, \ldots, x^{n-1} y, x^{n}, x^{n+1}\right)=\left(z_{0}, z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n+2}\right) \in \mathbb{C}^{n+3}
$$

is a complex surface germ $\left(X_{n}, 0\right)$ with an isolated singularity at the origin of $\mathbb{C}^{n+3}$ given by the equations:

$$
z_{n+1}^{k} z_{1}^{n-k} z_{k+1}=z_{n+2}^{k} z_{0}^{n-k}, 0 \leq k \leq n
$$

Again, by Theorem 4.1 the inner rate function $\mathcal{I}_{\mathfrak{m}_{n}}: \mathrm{NL}\left(X_{n}, 0\right) \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}^{*} \cup \infty$, where $\mathfrak{m}_{n}$ is the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X_{n}, 0}$, is completely determined by the inner rate function $\mathcal{I}_{I_{n}}: \mathrm{NL}\left(\mathbb{C}^{2}, 0\right) \longrightarrow$ $\mathbb{R}_{+}^{*} \cup \infty$ and since the ideals $I_{n}$ are distinct and integrally closed then, by Proposition 3.7, the inner rate functions $\left\{\mathcal{I}_{I_{n}}\right\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}^{*}}$ are also distinct. We can conclude using the inner rates formula 1.17 that $\left(\Gamma_{\pi_{n}}, L_{\pi_{n}}, P_{\pi_{p}}\right) \neq\left(\Gamma_{\pi_{m}}, L_{\pi_{m}}, P_{\pi_{m}}\right)$, for all $n \neq m$ in $\mathbb{N}$, where $\pi_{n}$ and $\pi_{m}$ are respectively the minimal good resolutions which factor through the blow-up of the maximal ideal and the Nash transform of $\left(X_{n}, 0\right)$ and $\left(X_{m}, 0\right)$ respectively.

Proof of Theorem 5.3. Let $I$ be an ideal of $\Lambda_{X}$. By Theorem 4.1, there exists a complete system of generators $F=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}\right)$ for $I$ and a complex surface germ $\left(X_{I}, 0\right) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}, 0\right)$ with an isolated singularity at the origin of $\mathbb{C}^{n}$ such that the map $F_{I}=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}\right):(X, 0) \longrightarrow\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ is a homeomorphism and a modification of the complex surface germ $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ embedded in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$. By Remark 4.2, the map $F_{I}$ is in particular a morphism of normalization. Furthermore, the map $F_{I}$ is such that the following diagram commutes
![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)
where $\mathfrak{m}_{I}$ is the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X_{I}, 0}$.
Let $\pi_{I}:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ be the minimal good resolution which factors through the blow-up of $I$ and the principalization of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$. The good resolution $F_{I} \circ \pi_{I}:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ factors through the blow-up of the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X_{I}, 0}$ and the Nash transform of $X_{I}$. Indeed, the family of linear forms $P=\left\{p_{i}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)=z_{i}\right\}_{1 \leq i \leq n}$ generate the ideal $\mathfrak{m}_{I}$ and the differentials $\left\{\mathrm{d} p_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} p_{j}\right\}_{1 \leq i, j \leq n}$ generates $\Omega_{\mathfrak{m}_{I}}^{2}$. Obviously, the family $\Pi_{P}$ coincide with the polar curves associated to the linear projections on $\mathbb{C}^{2}$ and we have that the $P^{*}:=\left(p_{1} \circ F_{I}=f_{1}, \ldots, p_{n} \circ F_{I}=f_{n}\right)=F$ which is a complete system of generators for the ideal $I$. By definition of the blow-up of $I$ and the principalization of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$, the good resolution $\pi_{I}:\left(X_{\pi}, E\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ has no basepoints for the families $L_{P^{*}}=L_{F}$ and $\Pi_{P^{*}}=\Pi_{F}$ and it follows that the good resolution $F_{I} \circ \pi_{I}$ has no basepoints for the families $L_{P}$ and $\Pi_{P}$. Then, by Proposition 2.4 and Theorem 5.7 we get that $F_{I} \circ \pi_{I}$ factors through the blow-up of the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X_{I}, 0}$ and the Nash transform of $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$. It remains to prove that $F_{I} \circ \pi_{I}$ is the minimal good resolution which have these properties. Assume it is not the case. Then, there exists a good resolution $\sigma_{I}:\left(Y_{I}, Z_{I}\right) \longrightarrow\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ which factors through $\mathrm{BL}_{\mathfrak{m}_{I}}$ and the Nash transform of $X_{I}$ such that $F_{I} \circ \pi_{I}$ factors through $\sigma_{I}$. On the other hand, since $\sigma_{I}$ is a good resolution, it factors through the normalization $F_{I}:(X, 0) \longrightarrow\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$. It implies that there exists a good resolution $r_{I}:\left(Y_{I}, Z_{I}\right) \longrightarrow(X, 0)$ such that $F_{I} \circ r_{I}=\sigma_{I}$.
![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)

In order to prove that $\sigma_{I}$ factors through $\pi_{I}$ we prove that $r_{I}$ factors through the blow-up of $I$ and the principalization of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$. Indeed, $r_{I}^{*}\left(F_{I}^{*}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{I}\right)\right)=r_{I}^{*}(I)=\sigma_{I}^{*}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{I}\right)$ which implies that $\sigma_{I}^{*}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{I}\right) \otimes \mathcal{O}_{Y_{I}}=r_{I}^{*}(I) \otimes \mathcal{O}_{Y_{I}}$. By Proposition 2.4, the ideal sheaf $\sigma_{I}^{*}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{I}\right) \otimes \mathcal{O}_{Y_{I}}$ is locally principal because $\sigma_{I}$ factors through $\mathrm{BL}_{\mathfrak{m}_{I}}$. It follows that $r_{I}^{*}(I) \otimes \mathcal{O}_{Y_{I}}$ is also locally principal which implies by Proposition 2.4 that $r_{I}$ factors through the blow-up $\mathrm{BL}_{I}$. Furthermore, $\sigma_{I}$ has no basepoints for the family $\Pi_{P}$ which implies that $r_{I}$ has no basepoints for the family $\Pi_{F}$, but it is not sufficient. In order for $r_{I}$ to factor through the principalization of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$ it needs to have no basepoints for any family $\Pi_{G}$, where $G$ is a precomplete system of generators for $I$. Let $G=\left(g_{1}, \ldots, g_{l}\right)$ be a precomplete system of generators for $I$. Since $G$ is precomplete then for every couple $(\alpha, \beta) \in \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ we have

$$
r_{I}^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} F_{\alpha} \wedge \mathrm{d} F_{\beta}\right)=\sum_{i \neq j} \psi_{i j}^{\alpha \beta} \pi^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} g_{i} \wedge \mathrm{~d} g_{j}\right)
$$

Let $p$ be a smooth point of an irreducible component $Z_{v}$ of $Z_{I}$. Let $(x, y)$ be a local coordinate system of $Y_{I}$ centered at $p$ such that $x=0$ is the equation of $Z_{v}$. By Lemma 2.11 we have

$$
r_{I}^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} F_{\alpha} \wedge \mathrm{d} F_{\beta}\right)=x^{\nu_{v}(I)} S_{\alpha \beta}(x, y) \mathrm{d} x \wedge \mathrm{~d} y, \text { with } S_{\alpha \beta}(0, y) \neq 0
$$

since $r_{I}$ has no basepoints for the family $\Pi_{F}$, there exists a Zariski open set $O_{p}$ of $\mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right) \times \mathbb{P}\left(\mathbb{C}^{k}\right)$ such that $S_{\alpha \beta}(0,0) \neq 0$ for all $(\alpha, \beta) \in O_{p}$. It follows from the equality (16) that there exists $i_{0}, j_{0} \in\{1, \ldots, l\}$ such that

$$
r_{I}^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} g_{i_{0}} \wedge \mathrm{~d} g_{j_{0}}\right)=x^{\nu_{v}(I)} S_{0}(x, y) \mathrm{d} x \wedge \mathrm{~d} y
$$

with $S_{0}(0,0) \neq 0$. It implies that there exists a Zariski open set $W$ such that for any $(\alpha, \beta)$ in $W$

$$
r_{I}^{*}\left(\mathrm{~d} G_{\alpha} \wedge \mathrm{d} G_{\beta}\right)=x^{\nu_{v}(I)} U_{\alpha \beta}(x, y) \mathrm{d} x \wedge \mathrm{~d} y
$$

where $U_{\alpha \beta}$ is a unit of $\mathbb{C}\{x, y\}$. It proves that $p$ is not a basepoint for the family $\Pi_{G}$. We can do the same if $p$ is a double point.

Now, we have proved that $r_{I}$ factors through the principalization of $\Omega_{I}^{2}$. By definition, it implies that $r_{I}$ factors through $\pi_{I}$. Finally, we proved that $\pi_{I} \circ F_{I}$ is indeed the minimal good resolution which factors through the blow-up of $\mathfrak{m}_{I}$ and the Nash transform of $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$.

By Proposition 5.4, for any two distinct integrally closed ideals $I$ and $J$ of $\Lambda_{X}$ we have $\mathcal{I}_{\mathfrak{m}_{I}} \neq$ $\mathcal{I}_{\mathfrak{m}_{J}}$ and it follows from Proposition 3.6 and the inner rates formula 1.17 that $\left(\Gamma_{\pi_{I}}, L_{\pi_{I}}, P_{\pi_{I}}\right) \neq$ $\left(\Gamma_{\pi_{J}}, L_{\pi_{J}}, P_{\pi_{J}}\right)$
5.1. Application to Outer Lipschitz geometry. As a corollary of Theorem 5.3, we can construct infinitely many complex surface germs with an isolated singularity that are not metrically equivalent in the Bilipschitz sense but have a common normalization.

First, let us recall some definitions and results about the bilipschitz geometry of complex germs (See [Pic20] for more details).
Definition 5.9. Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ embedded in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$. The outer metric $\mathrm{d}_{o}$ on $X$ is the metric induced by the ambient Euclidian metric, i.e., for all $x, y \in X, \mathrm{~d}_{o}(x, y)=\|x-y\|_{\mathbb{C}^{n}}$. The inner metric $\mathrm{d}_{i}$ on $X$ is the arc length metric induced by the ambient riemannian metric.
Definition 5.10. Let $(M, d)$ and $\left(M^{\prime}, d^{\prime}\right)$ be two metric spaces. A map $f: M \longrightarrow M^{\prime}$ is a bilipschitz homeomorphism if $f$ is a homeomorphism and there exists a real constant $K \geq 1$ such that

$$
\frac{1}{K} d(x, y) \leq d^{\prime}(f(x), f(y)) \leq K d(x, y), \forall x, y \in M
$$

Definition 5.11. Two analytic germs $(X, 0) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}, 0\right)$ and $\left(X^{\prime}, 0\right) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{m}, 0\right)$ are inner Lipschitz equivalent (resp. outer Lipschitz equivalent) if there exists a germ of bilipschitz homeomorphism $\psi:(X, 0) \longrightarrow\left(X^{\prime}, 0\right)$ with respect to the inner (resp. outer) metric. The equivalence class of the germ $(X, 0) \subset\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}, 0\right)$ for this equivalence relation is called the inner Lipschiz geometry (resp. outer Lipschitz geometry) of $(X, 0)$.

One of the main motivations for studying complex surface germs up to bilipschitz equivalence is that the biholomorphic type of a complex germ determines its bilipschitz geometry. Another motivation follows from a theorem by Mostowski [Mos85], which states that the set of inner (resp. outer) Lipschitz geometries is countable. While a complete classification of complex surface germs with isolated singularities has been given in [BNP14] the classification of complex surface germs up to outer Lipschitz equivalence is still open.

The next result aims to understand the set of outer Lipschitz geometries of complex surface germs with isolated singularities.

Corollary 5.12 (Corollary B). Let $(X, 0)$ be a normal complex surface germ. Let $\Lambda_{X}$ be the infinite set of integrally closed $\mathfrak{m}$-primary ideals of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$. There exists a family of complex surface germs with an isolated singularity $\left\{\left(X_{I}, 0\right)\right\}_{I \in \Lambda_{X}}$ such that
(i) $(X, 0)$ is homeomorphic to $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ for all $I \in \Lambda_{X}$ and is the common normalization of the germs $\left\{\left(X_{I}, 0\right)\right\}_{I \in \Lambda_{X}}$.
(ii) For all $I, J \in \Lambda_{X}$ the surfaces $\left(X_{I}, 0\right)$ and $\left(X_{J}, 0\right)$ are outer Lipschitz equivalent if and only if $I=J$.

Corollary 5.12 is a direct consequence of Theorem 5.3 and the following result of Neumann and Pichon

Theorem 5.13 ([NP16, Theorem 1.2]). Let $(X, 0)$ be a complex surface germ with an isolated singularity. Then the outer Lipschitz geometry of $X$ determines the triple $\left(\Gamma_{\pi}, L_{\pi}, P_{\pi}\right)$ where $\pi$ is the minimal good resolution which factors through the blow-up of the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{X, 0}$ and the Nash transform of $(X, 0)$.

abstract:
Let $(X, 0)$ be a normal complex surface germ embedded in $(\mathbb{C}^n,
0)$, and denote by $\mathfrak{m}$ the maximal ideal of the local ring
$\mathcal{O}_{X,0}$. In this paper, we associate to each $\mathfrak{m}$-primary
ideal $I$ of $\mathcal{O}_{X,0}$ a continuous function $\mathcal{I}_I$ defined
on the set of positive (suitably normalized) semivaluations of
$\mathcal{O}_{X,0}$. We prove that the function $\mathcal{I}_{\mathfrak{m}}$ is
determined by the outer Lipschitz geometry of the surface $(X, 0)$. We further
demonstrate that for each $\mathfrak{m}$-primary ideal $I$, there exists a
complex surface germ $(X_I, 0)$ with an isolated singularity whose
normalization is isomorphic to $(X, 0)$ and $\mathcal{I}_I =
\mathcal{I}_{\mathfrak{m}_I}$, where $\mathfrak{m}_I$ is the maximal ideal of
$\mathcal{O}_{X_I,0}$. Subsequently, we construct an infinite family of complex
surface germs with isolated singularities, whose normalizations are isomorphic
to $(X,0)$ (in particular, they are homeomorphic to $(X,0)$) but have distinct
outer Lipschitz types.
